structed by Mr. Mitchell, the superior landlord, not to pay the rent, and to caution all other tenants to the same effect. ) I showed that letter to Mr. Mitchell, and he said that it was false—I then wrote a letter demanding possession of the house—I did not get it till February last; but at the half quarter I sent and found from a party lodging there that it was let out in apartments—I put in a distress, and was sent for by the lodger, who said that the goods were his—I saw a woman, who referred me to Sidney—I said "Who is Sidney?"—she said "A man who lives in the kitchen below"—I sent for him to my office; he came; I asked him what right he had to send me a reference of that description, and put the letter before him—he said it would be all right; that Mr. Grey was a man of means, and would pay the rent when it was due—I said "Grey is in Holloway Gaol, and I am surprised to find that he has taken my property, and that he has two other houses in the same state," and I ordered him out of the place—I wrote to Grey, and after he got out of gaol I saw him about the middle of May—I asked him what he meant by taking the house and not occupying it—he said that his daughter objected to go to the house—I told him that his references were false and did not live there, and complained about his giving me the name of Sidney—he gave no explanation of that; no rent was ever paid—I distrained in January for the three quarters—all the goods were obtained by lodgers—I did not get possession till 1885, and it has cost me about 130l.—I believed that the referees were respectable people, an✗d I judged also by Grey's appearance—I believed that he was a man of means, and wanted the house for his own occupation; I would not have let the house to let out in lodgings. (MR. GEOGHEGAN here stated that the two Isetts wished to withdraw their pleas of
NOT GUILTY .)

SARAH SMITH . I am the wife of Francis Smith, a packer—we are now occupying 8 Block, Peabody Buildings—on 3rd April I took the third floor at 36, Essex Street, from Sidney—I paid my first week's rent through Mrs. Wilson; Sidney asked me for it—I told him that Mr. Grey had given me notice; he said that he was the landlord, and he would show me if I did not pay him, and next day he put in the brokers for three weeks, and I paid him to save my things being taken—I applied to a Magistrate—Sidney occupied the back kitchen and a room between the first and second floors—he sat down below and slept upstairs—there were other lodgers there, Mrs. Wilson was one—I have children; I had the rooms upstairs, but did not occupy them all—I went with Mrs. Wilson to 2, Bossborough Gardens, occupied by Grey—after going to the police-court I left 36; I would not trust myself there any longer.
Cross-examined by Sidney. Mr. Best paid you my rent, I believe; I paid it through Mrs. Wilson—I believe Mr. Best paid my week's rent when he paid Mrs. Wilson's.

HENRY YOUNG . I am a broker—in May last I had a warrant from Sidney, and on the 3rd I put in this notice of levy for 1l. 16s. for rent due by Mrs. Smith—I saw Sidney about it; he sent me a letter which I have at home—I went directly to his house—I knew no one in the matter but Sidney—I never got the rent and expenses from Mrs. Smith—a man was put in possession.
Cross-examined by Sidney. You signed the warrant—this is a copy of it. (This stated "By authority of your landlord, William Sidney.")

ALICE WILSON . I lodged in this house, 86, Essex Street—a man was put in possession, and I got him his dinner—Craner is the man, but I do not think he was put in the first time; they put a broker in three times—Craner put the other men in on Mr. Grey asserting that he was the landlord—I paid him 4l. for four weeks' rent for five rooms; this is his receipt, on 24th July, 1884, signed Richard Grey—I gave Sidney the money I had from Mrs. Smith the first week—I paid two weeks' rent for myself, and then I found that Mr. Grey was the landlord.

Cross-examined by Sidney. I lent Mrs. Smith the money to pay—prior to taking these apartments I wrote to you about taking a house, and you called on me—you found some premises for me, and I went to see them—I offered to give you references, and offered you a sovereign as commis
sion, but not till I got into the house—that was for obtaining the apart
ments—I paid the rent to you on account of Mr. Grey—I remained in the house some months after you and Mrs. Sidney left—there was no appli
cation by any one on your behalf for money; everything was paid for.

Re-examined. I first knew Mr. Grey a fortnight after I was in the house, and after I had handed over the money to Sidney—I received this letter from him—that refers to the house 37, Bessborough Gardens—I was going to take No. 2, Bessborough Gardens—I afterwards found that Gray resided there.

WILLIAM CRESSWELL . I am a house agent of 11, Houlden Terrace, Pimlico—Sidney applied to me in the name of Graham about taking a house in Battersea—this is one of his letters. (Signed H. Graham, and referring to R. Cramer, of South Belgravia, and B. Sidney, of 40, Nelson Square. ) Those persons were written to, and I got these replies from Cramer and Sidney. (MR. CUSSINS here stated that these letters were written, the first by Cramer and the second by Williams. ) I believed they were respectable people, and let him and his wife into possession at March quarter, 1885—he said that he had retired from the sea—he was arrested before any rent became due—after Sidney got possession of No. 27, Isett called and wanted to take No. 29.

Cross-examined by Sidney. I charged you a guinea for the agreement—was acting as agent for Mr. Tennant—this letter is signed by him. (This was a notice that Mr. Cresswell was no longer Mr. Tennant's agent, and that all rent was to be paid to Mr. Tennant direct, and that Mr. Cresswell had no authority to charge for the agreement. ) I had authority to let it—it had been empty perhaps six months, and wanted some repairs.

ELLEN LEWIN . My husband is a draftsman—on 20th April, 1885, we took lodgings at 19, Pratt Street, Lambeth, and paid the rent to Cramer and his wife—I was trying to sell a perambulator when the detective took

it away—I went to the House of Detention, after Cramer was locked up, to oblige his wife, and took a message from Sidney to Cramer that he had sent 52 or 56 pawn-tickets down to her mother's, and that Cramer would know whose mother it was, but he did not—Cramer told me that Sidney and Mrs. Williams were to keep out of the way—I gave that message to Sidney before he was taken.

Cross-examined by Sidney. I saw you in Lambeth on the day you were arrested, Monday—Mrs. Cramer was not at my house that day—I saw you with her, and she said, "This lady is going to get a note to my hus
band"—"lady" meant me.

HERBERT HAMLEY . I am warehouseman at Murdoch and Co.'s, 91 and 93, Farringdon Road—on 4th November, 1884, Mountford came to pur
chase a pier-glass for his son, whose name he gave as Isett—he wanted it on a hiring agreement—he gave the address 10, Churton Place, Vaux
hall Bridge Road, and said that his son was engaged at the Civil Service Stores—I sent the glass next day with this agreement. (This was signed Isett, Civil Service Stores, Westminster, and was an undertaking to keep the glass in his own custody, and not sell it till it was paid for. ) He paid me 10s.—he never paid any more—we sent our collector, and they were then gone—I saw the glass at the police-court in the custody of the police.

SARAH WAITE . I live at 110, Churton Place, Pimlico✗—Isett and his wife took lodgings with us about the middle of October last, they occupied the back parlour as Mr. and Mrs. Isett—two or three days afterwards Mountford came, but I never heard his name, they called him "Uncle," he was there every day except Sundays—I remember the pier-glass coming; I missed it a few days afterwards, I don't know how it went—they were there four weeks, they paid me 11s. and still owe me 13s.—after they left, Mountford called and asked for a letter for Isett—I spoke to him about some of my property which had been taken away, and he brought back a flat iron, but I did not get the rest—I went to 51, Southam Street, but could not make anybody hear—I called again and saw Mountford, who said if I would not call for the money he would bring me 5s. at a time till it was paid, but I never had any.

THOMAS GAMMON . I am a pawn-broker, of 44, Wilton Road—on 7th November, 1884, this pier-glass was pawned with me in the name of J. Mountford, 10, Charlwood Place, and on 21st November this carpet for 3l. in the same name, the owner has identified it.
Cross-examined by MR. DILL. I did not take in the carpet, I took in the pier-glass, but can't recollect who pawned it.

RICHARD HANCOCK . I am employed by Enoch Thomas, of Charles Street, Fitzroy Square—Isett came there on 15th November, 1884, and selected a carpet, value 5l. 8s., on the hire system—he described himself as of Suffolk Street, Pimlico, and that he had been an assistant at the Army and Navy Stores 12 months—he had not got any money then, but he afterwards paid 10s. deposit—the agreement was to be signed when the goods went home—this is it (produced), it is dated November 20th—Cramer brought the deposit to the shop the day before—I have identified the carpet, it is here, the pawnbroker showed it to me.

GEORGE GILLIARD . I am a carman—on 20th November I took a carpet to 51, Southam Street and took this agreement with me—I saw a woman—I asked for Mr. George Isett—Mountford came up and represented himself as George Isett—I showed him the agreement—he read it, signed
it, and I witnessed his signature—I do not recognise the woman, but if it was any one it was Mrs. Isett.
Cross-examined by MR. DILL. I recognise Mountford.

FREDERICK HENRY SNEAD . I am a boot and shoe maker of 86, Kenning
ton Road—at the end of November last Sidney came there in the name of Charles Carter to take the house—I asked him to give me references, and afterwards received this letter. (Giving a reference, R. Cramer, Esq., of Sutherland Street, South Belgravia. ) I wrote to them and received this reply: "Dear Sir,—In reply to your letter, C. Carter has rented under me and I have no hesitation in recommending him as a respectable tenant. Signed R. Cramer." Carter said that he was going to occupy it as a private house, he was not to let lodgings—he said that he would respect my wishes—I believed the reference to be a respectable person and that he had been a tenant of Cramer's for some years—when the quarter's rent became due I went, but could not find Carter—I met him in Kensington Road a day or two before he was taken in custody—I never got any rent, I have got possession of the house—I used to see Thomas Williams come up the area steps and Mrs. Williams or Dundas, they occupied the basement.
Cross-examined by MR. DILL. They were ordinary lodgers, and I had no power over them.

Cross-examined by Sidney. My solicitor commenced an action against you—you made an appointment to see me on Thursday evening at 6 o'clock; you called on Wednesday, and I was not there—Inspector Marshall has some of your letters—I did not say that I did not mind what Mr. Carter was, so long as he paid me my rent—the people next day gave me information that you were coiners, and I sent a man to try and get into the house, but could not; I did get in one evening when you were away.

JOHN HENRY SPENCER . I am a coal merchant, of Kennington Road—I got an order for two tons of the best Wallsend coal, in the name of Carter; I sent the coals, but did not get the money—I went a day or two afterwards and saw Mrs. Dundas, she said that she was a lodger there—I saw no one else; she said that Mr. Carter was away, she would tell him as soon as he cause in—I left a message with her that we should send for the coals and remove them, or sue for the money—about three days afterwards I knocked at the door and Mrs. Dundas came up the steps—I asked if Mr. Carter was there, she said "No," he had not come home—I heard some one in the coal-cellar; the door was locked, I went down and opened it, and saw the prisoner Williams in the cellar filling some sacks with the coals—I said "What are you doing there? you are sacking the coals"—he rushed out, and said "You speak of suing for the coals or fetching them away; the first b—that comes down these stairs I will knock his head off"—I think he was sober—after he had finished he locked the door, and turned to me and said "Now you can try if you like"—I never got the money or the coals,

JOSEPH WILLIS . I am a cheesemonger, of 5, Brunswick Place, Parson's Green—on 9th April Williams and a man named McNamara called at my place—Williams had sold me some coals one or two days before, and he asked me if I could take.half a ton of coals, as a gentleman was going to move from a house in Kennington Road, and did not want to leave them—that is a long way from Fulham—he mentioned 10s. as the price, which

I gave him, and got his receipt afterwards—it was not a good half ton—he did not come and hawk them—I did not know that he had them from Mr. Spencer on March 27th. (MR. OVEREND here stated that the prisoner Mountford would PLEAD GUILTY. )

WILLIAM NCNAMARA . I carried these coals from 86, Kennington Road, and saw Mr. and Mrs. Williams (Dundas)—Williams walked a little way with me, and then jumped up in the van and rode with me to Mr. Willis's, and we delivered the coals—he borrowed 12 of our hundred-weight sacks; it filled them; besides that two half hundredweight sacks and two quarters were delivered at 29, Victoria Road, Battersea, before we went to Mr. Willis—Williams put them into my van—I saw no one at 29, Victoria Road, I only shot them into the cellar.
Cross-examined by MR. DILL. I saw Mrs. Williams in the area of 29, Victoria Road, she stood looking on while the coals were loading.

JOHN LEWIN . I am a salesman to Mr. Lipscombe, a filter manufac
turer, of 233, Strand—I received this letter: "86, Kennington Road, 26/9/85. Gentlemen,—I have looked over your catalogue, and ordered a filter at 70s. Charles Carter." The filter was sent the next day, the terms were cash down—I got no money, but three days afterwards I got this letter from Mr. Williams to send another filter the same size. (This was written on crested paper, ordering a filter, to hold three or four gallons, and was signed R. Grey. ) In July, 1884, I parted with the first filter to Grey—I did not get paid, and in April I got an order from Carter for another; they then attempted to get a third in the name of Williams.

Cross-examined by MR. OVEREND. I made the first application for pay
ment to Grey about a month after the filter was sold—I did not know that he has had it in use ever since.

Re-examined. The price was 3l. 10s.—we have called occasionally, but there was no one in, and we did not get the money—when I was giving evidence at the police-court Grey said "That is my letter, and I had the filter."

RICHARD MORTIMER . I am carman to Lipscombe and Co.—I had to take a filter to 86, Kennington Road on 29th April—I saw Mrs. Wil
liams; she answered to the name of Carter—I said that I had brought a filter; she told me to bring it in—I left the invoice f✗or 3l. 10s.—she said that Mr. Carter was not in, and he would send a cheque—she signed my delivery-book "C. Carter."

LOUISA CHITTY . I live at Marsh Gate, Richmond—on 15th April Grey called with a lady, who I have since seen; he gave the name of Paget—I gave him the key of a house No. 1, The Peldon—the day afterwards I received this letter. (This was signed William Paget, 27, Victoria Road, Battersea Park, stating that he was willing to take the house if he took posses
sion at once. ) My clerk then wrote to Mr. Graham, of 27, Victoria Road, and got this letter in reply. (This was from H. Graham, stating that Mr. Paget had rented under him, and had always been punctual to his engagements, and would be found a capab'e tenant. ) I also had another letter from Paget, stating that he had signed the agreement, and would call next day for the keys—he got possession on condition that he did the repairs.

Cross-examined by MR. OVEREND. He did not mention the name of Grey—I told his wife she had better get out, and she sent the keys—no rent was due till September—as to doing up the house and garden, here is a specimen of his rep✗airs. (Producing a corks✗crew. )

GEORGE COX . I lived at 6, Brunswick Place, Parson's Green—I have known Williams about 12 months—about the beginning of June he said that he had got two perambulators, one which cost five guineas and another seven, and a filter and some Irish linen, all in pledge—he gave me a list of them, stating what he wanted for the pawn-tickets; he also said he had a Bible in pledge for 30s., which cost three guineas; that the gentleman who had it would get it out and let me have it—I gave him 5s. for the tickets for some table and bed linen, for which I paid 16s. to Mr. Attenborough, of Newington Butts—I saw Dundas on the morning of the summons at Westminster and I met Williams and Grey.
(Grey here stated that he would PLEAD GUILTY. )

Cross-examined by Williams. I bought a bed of you for 6s.—I don't know whose ticket it was, I have pledged it since—I know you sell things on commission, pawn-tickets or anything else—you wanted to borrow my van to move some things from Wandsworth—I understood that Mr. Grey had some things which he wanted to move to Richmond—you went to Willis and were very nasty because they would not let you have a van—one was afterwards got from Bollinger, of Notting Hill.

GEORGE ROBERTS . In November, 1884, I had the letting of 33, Mark
ham Street—Cramer took it at a rent of 75l., and referred to R. Sidney, from whom I received this letter. (Stating that Cramer would make a re
spectable tenant) Cramer then got possession—no rent was paid.

RAMSEY MORRIS . I am clerk to the Newcastle Colliery owners—about 6th January, 1885, I got this order. (Signed E. Carter, for Wallsend coals. ) We delivered the coals to 86, Kennington Road, and this signa
ture, "C. Carter," was brought back—we never got the money.
Cross-examined by Sidney. I applied for it a few weeks afterwards—we do not give credit.

GEORGE JAMES AYRES . I am a clerk, and live at 86, Kennington Road—I rented four rooms of Carter, that is Sidney, and I live there still—Mr. and Mrs. Williams lived there as man and wife, as Mr. and Mrs. Dundas.

Sidney's Defence. The filter and the perambulator were bought on the credit system, payable by instalments. I should have met the engage
ments; I was receiving money at the time. I am a mariner, and since that I have expended 4,000l. as a dealer in property; no one can say that I owe a shilling.
Thomas Williams's Defence. I have had nothing but a half-hundred weight of coal. I have been in prison three months, and I was never in prison before. I could have given more references.

p.hi:
was further indicted for a previous conviction at Clerken
well, upon which

div1.p: NOT GUILTY.

GEORGE ISETT, CRAMER, and GREY.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour each.
EMMA ISETT and DUNDAS.—
Six Months' Hard Labour each.
MOUNTFORD.—
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.
SIDNEY and THOMAS WILLIAMS.—
Twenty Months' Hard Labour each.

880.
WILLIAM DENNING WADE ,
Unlawfully attempting to abuse
Florence Clapham, aged 14 years. Second Count for an indecent assault.

881.
THOMAS DAVIES (40),
Robbery with violence on
John Caffrey, and stealing a watch and chain, his property.

JOHN CAFFREY . I am a commissioner—on 2nd September, between 12 and 1 a.m., I was in Chandos Street, and was suddenly struck on my mouth, rendered senseless, and my watch taken—I did not see who did it, but I saw the prisoner running, and pursued him, crying "Stop thief"—I fell over a step, and when I got up I found him in custody—I have not seen my watch since.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. At the time the man snatched my watch I saw nobody else there—a boy pointed you out—I saw no one running after you when I got up.

WILLIAM FRAZIER . I live at 5, Turner's Court, Bedfordbury—I was in the Strand, selling newspapers, and saw the prisoner at the back entrance to Toole's Theatre; he struck Caffrey on his mouth, stole his watch and chain, and ran—I halloaed "Stop thief," and followed, and spoke to a policeman—he ran into a crowd, but I watched where he ran, and am sure he is the man.
Cross-examined. I sell newspapers—I had sold them all—my father is a painter; he is in prison for nine months.

HENRY HIGGINS (Policeman E 254). On 2nd September, about a quarter to 1 a.m., I was on duty in Bedfordbury, heard cries of "Stop thief," and saw the prisoner running—I chased him along Chandos Street to Adelaide Street—he placed himself among 20 or 30 other men, and Frazier came up and pointed him out—I took him out of the crowd, and said he would have to go with me—he said "What for? I have done nothing"—I said "You stole the gentleman's watch"—I am sure he is the man I saw running, after I heard the cry.
Cross-examined. The prosecutor's mouth was flowing with blood.

Prisoner's Defence. I went into the crowd to see what was going on, and stood there two or three minutes, and the boy came up and said "That is the man." The policeman said "Has he struck you?" He said "No, I fell over a step and hurt my nose."
JOHN CAFFREY (Re-examined). I said that the man struck my nose and made it bleed—I fell over the step afterwards.

GUILTY . He then
PLEADED GUILTY
to a conviction at Westminster on 23rd July, 1877, in the name of Henry Batts; thirteen previous convictions were proved against him, and he had still two years and four months to serve of a former sentence of seven years' penal servitude.—
Nine Months' Imprisonment after completing his former sentence .

882.
HENRY OSCAR (28),
Unlawfully obtaining 3s. from
Lionel Carlisle, 5s. from
Frank Butterfield, and 5s. from
James Laurence Ben
guard, with intent to defraud.

JAMES LAURENCE BENGUARD . I am a clerk at 33, Chancery Lane—on July 31st the prisoner came there, and said that he had some theatre tickets to sell, and I gave him 5s. for a dress circle ticket for the Lyceum—I heard something, and went to see the manager, who said it was a forgery—the prisoner afterwards wrote to me asking me to return the ticket, as the free list was suspended, and he would get the date altered—I went with the manager to Bow Street and swore an information.
Cross examined. You made yourself known to me by mentioning several
gentlemen who had bought tickets of you, and that is why I bought the tickets—when I gave information to the police I believed you intended to cheat me of the 5s., and I think so now.

CHARLES DREW (Detective E). On 24th August I took the prisoner on a warrant for defrauding Mr. Benguard, and said that it was by means of a forged order for the Lyceum Theatre—he said "I never wrote the orders, another man wrote them and gave them to me; I sold them, and we both shared the money"—I have a great number of other tickets.

Cross-examined. You gave me the name and address of the man you said you had them from—you said that you would not put us to any trouble, you would plead guilty to all of it; that you were hard up, and wanted some money, and did not know what to do—I asked your wife if the had any tickets or letters.

LIONEL CARLISLE . I live at 6, Park Road—on 13th or 14th July I heard that the prisoner had an order for the Lyceum Theatre, and I went out and asked him how much it was—he said that he usually got 6s. for a dress circle ticket—I said that it was a great deal more than I could pay, and he came down to 3s.—I afterwards gave it to Mr. Stoker, who said it was forgery—this is it.

FRANK BUTTERFIELD . I am a clerk, of 82, Old Broad Street—the prisoner had been there before, and on July 16th he came and produced a ticket admitting two to the dress circle of the Lyceum Theatre on Monday, July 20th, which he offered me for 6s.—I expressed my surprise—he assured me that they were genuine, and said that he had a friend at Court, and on the strength of that I gave him 5s. for the ticket—I pre
scribed it on the 20th at the theatre, was told that it was worthless, and I had to pay—next morning I got this letter from the prisoner. (Dated July 20th, telling the witness not to go, as the seats were all booked for that night, and to keep the ticket till he called for it to-morrow. Signed, "O.") I then went to the Lyceum and saw Mr. Stoker—the prisoner did not call next day—this is the ticket he sold me.
Cross-examined. I said a few days before that if you would get me a couple of tickets for the Lyceum I would buy them.

BRANS TOKER . I am acting manager at the Lyceum Theatre—I think I have seen the prisoner before, but cannot call to mind where—these two tickets are not genuine—the prisoner had no authority to dispose of tickets under Mr. Irving's management—there are no complimentary orders except to Mr. Irving's friends.
Cross-examined. You are not a member of the profession, and would not be entitled to complimentary tickets.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that the tickets were not written by him, but that he bought them of Frank Maynard, of Newington Butts, of Cook's Circus Company and St. James's Theatre, and sold them, believing them to be genuine, and that Maynard's landlady and the manager of the Carpenters' Arms could both prove this; that it was customary to buy and sell complimentary tickets, and it was as easy for him to buy them as any one else, and that he had a pupil, a friend of Mr. Irving's, who he would lose had he committed such an offence.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

883.
JULES BARNARD (32),
FRANCIS PAUL LAUNET (29) and
CHARLES LINDEN (32),
Obtaining rom✗
Louis Sindoux Dutap 10 francs by false pretences, with intent to defraud, and other sums from other persons with a like intent. Other Counts for conspiracy. (
GIOVANNI DOMPE
was also charged in the indictment together with the prisoners, but the
COMMON SERJEANT quashed the indictment as against him.

LOUIS ARISTIDES SINDOUX DUTAP (Interpreted). I am a journalist, for
merly of Namur, now living at 32 1/2, Greek Street—I saw an advertise
ment to the effect, but not in the same words, as this one. (This stated that servants of both sexes were wanted for England, that English was not necessary, and that expenses would be refunded; application to be made to Barnard, 21A, Noel Street, Berwick Street, London; 30 centimes to be enclosed for an answer. ) I wrote to Barnard and received this letter in reply. (This had a printed heading, French Registry Office, &c., J. Bar
nard, director, 21, Noel Street, and stated that they had several situations as professors in schools, with salaries from 100 to 200 francs per month, with board and lodging, or as French correspondent with 75 to 300 francs a month, or as correspondence clerk and bookkeeper at a firm of diamond merchants at 400 a month, and requesting him to send references and 10 francs for inquiry fee, and adding they would charge 5 per cent. on the first year's salary as commission. ) I sent references and 10 francs to Barnard, and received this letter from him dated 10th July. (Stating that in eight days they would be able to put him into communication with the diamond merchants who required a clerk and bookkeeper, and who they hoped would accept his services. ) In consequence of that I came over to England on 25th July, and went to 21, Noel Street two or three days after my arrival, but saw none of the prisoners there—I was told to call again, and I went again next day, when I saw the three prisoners—I asked for Mr. Barnard; Launet came forward as if he were he—he said the place for which I came had been taken two or three days before, but that they had a place at that moment which would suit me, and to which I should be introduced; that was to be the director of Mr. Dompe's club at 40, Charlotte Street, near Fitzroy Square—I went there with Linden, who called himself Durant, and after having a glass to drink he introduced me to Dompe—after doing so he said, "Now I have intro
duced you to Dompe, and if you suit him we shall speak of the matter to-night"—we did not speak of business that day, but next day I went again with Linden to the place, and then Linden spoke to Dompe by himself, after which he informed me that Mr. Dompe expressed now some objection to my getting the place, and that he asked a deposit of 10,000 francs, but that through his intervening with Dompe on my behalf Dompe would be satisfied with 3,000 francs—I told him I would write home for the 3,000 francs and try to get them—Linden said, "Remain here and write the letter," and then he left—I afterwards went to Noel Street, where I saw Linden, and said Dompe did not require a servant, but somebody to take charge of the club, with 3,000 francs deposit—Linden said, "If your father should object to pay the money from hand to hand without depositing it at a bank, let your father

sign a bill, which I will hand over to Dompe, and he will be satisfied with that"—after that I called several times at Noel Street and always saw the prisoners there; I have seen all three at Dompe's house—I chiefly dealt with Linden—I got no situation—the police informed me not to deposit any money, and I did not do so.

Cross-examined by Barnard. Although you did not write to me posi
tively to come over, the meaning of your letter was to that effect, and I believed I was to come because you said you would put me into direct communication with the place—I received no letter saying that if I was wanted they would write to me to come over—I never asked you to repay me the 10 francs—I saw you in Dompe's cellar, where I went to taste some wines; I cannot say if once or several times.
Cross-examined by Launet. You did not say you were Barnard, you always spoke and acted as if you were; you took no further part in my affairs—it was Linden with whom I had to do.

Cross-examined by Linden. I thought "direct communication" meant face to face—I received from you the address of a Mr. Beck with regard to being a professor at his place, but there also 5,000 francs was required—you never took me to him—I gave the 10 francs to cover small expenses—you spent a little money with me in drinks, not 10 francs; I spent a good deal more—you lent me 1l. 7s. (I did not ask you to) when you found I was about to telegraph for some money—I wrote, and an answer by return of post enclosing 200 francs came to my name at Barnard's address—the prisoners opened the letter, but the money was by draft and they could not get it; they gave me the letter opened—I returned the 1l. 7s.—it is possible that at the police-court I did not mention the sum of 10,000 francs which I was asked at Dompe's—I never said Dompe told me he did not want any employe—I did not know he was in want of a confidential person to take an interest in the business and deposit 3,000 francs—I should have had one or another place if I had deposited a lot of money—Barnard's firm have not fulfilled their obligations because their letters never mentioned anything about a deposit—it is true your letter mentioned simply the places and nothing about the terms.
Re-examined. The police came and warned me on the first day I went to the prisoners' place.

JOSEPH VON DEN DRIES . I am now living at 5, Portland Street, Soho, but up to July was in Antwerp—I then saw an advertisement in the Precurseur, in consequence of which I wrote to J. Barnard, 21, Noel Street, and received this reply. (Dated 20th July, and stating they had ad
vantageous situations at their disposal, and requesting him to send particulars of himself and references, and 10 francs for enquiry fee, adding that their fee would be five per cent. on the first year's salary. ) I wrote to Barnard, 21, Noel Street, in consequence of that letter, enclosing 10 francs—I received this letter. (Dated 23rd July, and stating that in 10 days they would place him in communication with the owner of a firm of provision dealers. ) On 1st August I came to London, and went to 21, Noel Street—the door was locked and no one there—I went there again, I think the same day, and saw Barnard—I asked if Mr. Barnard was at home; he said "No," and told me to return, and I did so, and then saw all three prisoners there—when I asked for Barnard then Linden came forward and said he would get me a place, but that Monday being a bank holiday there was no one in the City—I went there again on the Tuesday, when Linden told me the bank

holiday was only a holiday for the clerks, but that the principals prolonged their holiday during the whole week—two days after he gave me a note to Mr. Dompe, and told me to go there, but to speak of nothing till he came, and he gave me a memorandum to get my dinner there; he was a member of the club—I went there; it is a club in Charlotte Street; I had dinner, and waited till Linden and Launet came—Linden and Dompe spoke together, and then Linden told me to go upstairs to take a cup of coffee, and on the staircase he told me Dompe would give me 400 francs a month to be the manager of his provision and wine warehouse—he said Dompe was going to give 300 francs at first, but he interceded, and he then consented to raise it to 400 francs—I had not said whether I had any experience of the wine business—in the passage Linden took me on one side and said, "Now the matter is arranged, but a deposit of 300 francs is required"—I told him I had no money at the time, but on writing to my mother no doubt I could get it—he said he would write a letter as well to my mother in support of my application, and he said, "Your mother can send the money to me or Mr. Barnard"—on that day my week's lodging terminated—I went to take my box away from Bar
nard's office and found the door locked and no one there, and all the things, including my own, were seized—then Inspector Moser spoke to me.

Cross-examined by Barnard. I have lost my 10 francs through you, and the passage-money to London and my expenses here and my time—you did not positively write for me to come over here, but your letter said, "I am quite sure to put you into a place"—that was a letter addressed to Mr. Gaillard, a friend of mine (Moser has the letter)—we had been writing together—he had not sent the 10 francs; I applied what you said to him to myself—I never asked you to return the 10 francs—Dompe's was the only place you introduced me to—it was more than a week before you were taken into custody.
Cross-examined by Launet. I had nothing to do with you, nor you with me; I always saw you in the office.

Cross-examined by Linden. You did not say you were Mr. Barnard, but came forth as such when I asked—Dompe's wine and provision business was situated at another address than that of the club—you wanted me to send the 3,000 francs to your address; it was to be handed over to Dompe, but I don't believe you would have done so—I was in the same house with my friend—you told him you had been established seven years—my box was returned to me.

EUGENE TAICHT . I am now living at 3, Rupert St., and am an agricul
tural labourer, near Rouen—on 19th July I saw an advertisement similar to this in the Petit Journal. (This stated that French male and female servants were required for England; travelling expenses refunded; write to Barnard, 21, Noel Street. ) I wrote to that address. (Mentioning the advertisement and asking for the names of the employments where a married couple without children were required. )—I received this reply from J. Barnard, dated 25th July. (This stated that the following situations were at his disposal: "Manager of a French hotel and restaurant, 600 francs per month, for man and wife; manager of an artistic club, 450 francs per month, and board and lodging; situations as valet and cook in one family, 4,000 francs a year; a butler at 7,000 francs a year; and that good servants were wanted at wages from 1,800 to 6,000 francs a year, and cooks and maids of all sorts; asking for references and 10 francs for inquiry fees, and adding that as soon

as they heard which situation would suit them best they would put them in direct communication with the house they wished to be placed in. ) I wrote on 31st July (Saying they intended coming to London between the 15th and 20th of the month, and he would then like the situation of manager to the hotel at 600 francs a month, or that of manager to the French artistic club at 450 francs a month with board and lodging). I received this answer, signed "pro J. Barnard," and dated 31st July. (This stated that if he wished a place reserved he must send references and 10 francs, and they would then send him the name of their client, and they could settle the matter between themselves.) On 4th August I wrote. (Enclosing 10 francs, and begging him to pay attention to it, as he would be in London at the end of the week). On 7th August I came to London and called at 21A, Noel Street; the door was locked—I went again an hour and a half afterwards, and found Barnard and Launet there—I asked for Barnard; Launet said "What do you want?"—I told him my name, and said I had come for the place which he had told me in his letter he had ready and was keeping for me—he told me managership of the hotel was filled, but he would find me a place in two or three days—I called next day, and saw Barnard and Launet there—I asked again for Barnard, and Launet answered as he had done before—Linden then came in, and I was introduced to him, and was told he had a warehouse in Paris, and imported English goods over, and vice versa—Linden then proposed that I should go back to Paris to take the delivery of some goods he would purchase here in Paris into my hands, and he wanted a deposit of 3,000 francs as security—I told him I had no such sum at my disposal—Linden left, and I told the other two I should try to get my money before I went, before the end of the week—I got no situation—I did not ask for the 10 francs, nor did I have them.

Cross-examined by Barnard. I lost my 10 francs and my expenses in coming and staying over here—you did not tell me to come, but gave me to understand that the place was ready for me—you did not blame me when I arrived, but said "If I don't get you a place to-day I am sure to get you one to morrow"—you introduced me to no place—you proposed to me the place of door porter at the French Hospital, but you never took me there; these were all falsehoods.
Cross-examined by Launet. You did not positively say "I am Barnard," but I took you to be him.

Cross-examined by Linden. I only saw you at Noel Street, where you came as if you were looking for a servant, and Launet introduced you to me—I did not come over at your special invitation—the letter I received said: "If you wish us to reserve one of 12 places it becomes necessary to send us papers, references, and 10 francs; we shall then put you in communication with the place, and you can arrange the matter between yourselves; in this way you will be sure of the place, while otherwise we could not guarantee to secure it for you."

EDMOND DUBOURG . I am a musician, of Rouen, and am now living at 1, Noel Street—on 20th July I saw an advertisement in the Petit Journal offering places to everybody—I wrote in consequence to 21, Noel Street, and received this letter in answer. (Stating that they could procure him a situation as French correspondent clerk in a commercial house at 150 francs a month to commence with; that if a talented cornet player they could procure him an engagement at one of the London music halls; or if capable of playing

variations on the cornet like To✗ntiet, of Paris, they could get him a splendid engagement: asking for 10 francs for inquiry fees, and adding would he prefer the post of whip to one of the great houses. ) I wrote, enclosing 10 francs—I received this answer on 3rd August. (Stating that they had learnt of a situation to suit him as the inspectorship of the Orpheus Musicians' Club, 40, Charlotte Street, Oxford Street, at a salary of 150 francs a month, board and lodging, and where, as he would only have to superintend, he might utilise his time in giving lessons; and they said he might write on their behalf to M. Giovanni Dompe at the address of the club. ) On receiving that I came to London, and called at 21, Noel Street on the day of my arrival—the prisoners were then in prison.
Cross-examined by Barnard. The only meaning in your letter was that I should come.
Cross-examined by Linden. In the newspaper you said travelling expenses would be repaid—you said you had a place that would certainly suit me, and I believed you.

CHARLES MEURANT . I am a commercial clerk, now living at 5, Port-land Street—in a Lille newspaper, where I was then living, I read an advertisement, in consequence of which I wrote to Mr. Jules Barnard and received this letter of 26th July. (This gave a list of places which seemed suitable; asked him to let them know which would suit and to enclose 10 francs for inquiry fees. ) I wrote enclosing 10 francs, and in answer received this letter of 3rd August from J. Barnard. (Stating that his statement had been sent on to Charles Linden, importer, 61, Hatton Garden, requesting him to write relative to securing a couriership, and hoping that when the contract was signed he would forward five per cent. commission on first year's salary. ) I then wrote to Mr. Charles Linden, 61, Hatton Garden, and got this letter in answer. (Stating that with reference to the place as courier, for which they had charged Mr. Barnard to find a steady person their terms were 700 francs a year, payable monthly, without reckoning travelling expenses, which would be 8s. a day while in Paris and second-class travelling fare; that he would have to deposit 3,000 francs as a guarantee; that he could enter the service tn September, and that they were willing to accept him if he accepted the conditions; while, if they considered an interview necessary, they would inform him. ) After that I came to London and went to 21, Noel Street on 13th August, where I saw Barnard and Launet—the latter came forward when I asked for Barnard—I asked for the house of Linden and produced the correspondence, as they did not know me—I said to Launet "I find it rather strange that a commercial clerk is required to deposit a sum of money like that"—he said the reason was because I should have to collect money to a large amount in Paris—I accepted the explanation—Launet said "Come at 5 o'clock"—I came and found the police in possession.

Cross-examined by Barnard. You made me lose the place at Amiens in which I was at the time, 10 francs, and intended to make me lose 3,000 francs—I came over thinking I would better myself—your letter had "Registry Office" at the top—I came to London because Linden said "I accept you if you accept the terms of the engagement," and one of the letters said "You enter into your place on 15th September"—you never said that you were Launet, but you always acted as if you were—your house had only existed two or three days, and was therefore incapable of giving the employment promised on the terms stated—there was only a

table and a few things at Colonial Buildings; and the whole aspect of the place led me to believe no business was carried on—I do not know whether you have goods belonging to customers or not—I came at 5 o'clock and found some one who told me you were all in custody and it was useless to look for the place.

JULE FLAXELL HINDLET (Interpreted). I am a wine and provision merchant—in July last a Mr. Gull introduced Linden to me as a customer—I asked him what kind of goods he would want—he said wines and provisions—he told me he had registry offices in Belgium, France, and England—I asked him where his office was, and he said "Near to your house"—he asked me if I required a partner or manager, accountant, book-keeper, or clerk, and he would get me one—I told him as the business was getting on better now I should like to have a partner if I could get a suitable person for the business—the next day Linden asked me to come to his office—the prisoners came to my place—Launet said "If you will come at 5 o'clock to my place I wish to speak to you"—I went with Gull to Noel Street—the prisoners and another man were there—Linden said "I have written to France and other parts, and two gentlemen will come, and I have no doubt that one of the two will suit you; I will cause him to deposit 3,000 or 5,000 francs in my pocket, and then I will send him to you to treat; once I have the money in my pocket, and you have come to terms with them yourself, I shall prepare the agreement," the terms of which were that the money was to be paid as a loan at six months' interest in advance—I said "Well, if one of these gentlemen call upon me and I find him suitable I will accept him"—he said "You call him a gentleman, I call him a type," meaning a man not of great consequence, or "one of the set"—I said "Well, if the man suits me I will make an inventory of my stock, and will take him as a partner; I shall then have an agreement drawn up by a solicitor, and if we should dissolve partnership the money will be refunded to him"—he said "No, no, that must not be done like that; in a little while you will pick a quarrel with him somehow or other, and turn him out of doors, then send him to me, and I will just give him a touch of my boot to a certain part, and send him back to his own country, and you need not return him the money before the expiration of the contract in three or five years accordingly"—I did not fall in with the arrangement—I communi
cated with the police—this occurred the beginning of July.

Cross-examined by Launet. If I said before the Magistrate that I saw Linden first it was because I never knew your names correctly, and made a mistake; I meant the man in the middle (Launet)—the interpreter at the police-court was so bad that he did not understand what I said, at all events you (Launet) are the man I meant, and you must not forget I am on my oath—I said Linden because I heard Linden so often that I made a muddle of it—on the first occasion Gull introduced me to you (Launet), for on the second I saw you all three together—it was Linden who spoke to me first at Noel Street.

Cross-examined by Linden. You proposed that I would have people come over from foreign parts who would part with their money for a certain purpose, and you would forward them to me with instructions to kick them out of the house—no doubt you believed I was a man who would fall in with your views in this matter, but I was in communication with a
person sent by the police—I never had any correspondence with you, if there is any it is a forgery.

MAURICE MOSER (Police Inspector). The conduct of this case was placed in my hands, in consequence of which I went on 13th August to 21, Noel Street, with Detective Howell, about 3 p.m.—I saw Barnard and Launet—I said "We are police officers, I am to arrest Barnard on a warrant for having defrauded Mr. Taicht"—I said to Mr. Taicht, who was with us, "Point out to me Barnard," and he pointed to Launet—I said to Launet "Are you Barnard?" he said "No, my name is Launet"—Barnard then said "I am Barnard"—I then said "I hold a warrant against you"—I read the warrant to him in French—he said "We did not write these letters to the people to tell them to come over to London, they ought to have remained in France"—MM. Sindoux Dutap, and Saumi came in and said "We have come for our situation, we sent you the 10 francs, and wish to enter it"—I asked them to point out Barnard to me: they pointed to Launet—I said to Launet "I shall take you also in custody for conspiring with Barnard to defraud M. Taicht out of 10 francs"—I then took them to Marlborough Street Police-station and charged them—I fouod upon Barnard a pocket-book containing a postal order for 10 francs, addressed to 21A, Noel Street—at 52, Great New
man Street I found several letters addressed to Barnard; also bill-heads of Bourg and Co., 222, Lancaster Road—we then returned to Noel Street and searched, and found 136 certificates, over 2,000 letters, a quantity of bill-heads in the name of Barnard, Charles Linden, and Durant—a number of the bill-heads had on them a printed stereotyped letter, and there were various forms addressed to ladies and to gentle
men, one to a lady in the name of Beaurant and Co.—I also found some (account) books, a printing press, and rather new type—from about 9.30 to 10 I went with Howell to 58, Radnor Street, Chelsea—in answer to inquiries a woman replied, and we had to wait a considerable time—when Linden arrived I said "What is your name, Linden?"—he said "Yes;" I said "We are police officers, and are going to arrest you for conspiring with Barnard and Launet to defraud M. Taicht out of 10 francs"—he said "None of these persons can produce a document that we asked them to come to London"—I said "Is not your real name Brillon?" he denied it, hesitated, and then said "Yes"—I said "Under what name are you going now?" he said "Linden, of 59, 60, and 61, Hatton Garden; here are my keys, if you go there you will find a clerk to-morrow morning"—I went and found a portfolio containing a foreign newspaper with an advertisement in it, also a quantity of papers addressed to Barnard and Co., also these two books, in which are entries of receipts for post-office orders, all for 7s. 8d., or 10 francs, and "Sindoux 7s. 8d.," and "Dutap" and "Dubourg" for 7s. 6d., "Van den Dries" for 7s. 8d., and "Meurant" for 7s. 8d.; and in the other book "Taicht 10 francs;" I also found this sheet of post-office orders, marked by the prisoners, 65 altogether—I counted between 20th June and 18th July, 125 post-office orders—it was a large office in one house—there was a desk, table, and three chairs; no business books beyond these two—we found a great many letters—from August 14th to 17th they received 230 letters, con
taining 13 post-office orders, addressed to Barnard and Linden—we found at Noel Street a book with entries in different places; also Mr. Hind
let's name as proprietor of and successor to the business at 31, Old Comp
ton

Street, of wine merchant, &c.—I found the name of Dompe three times for three situations, and one as manager to a club in Charlotte Street—I had 222, Lancaster Road under observation from the middle of May, from communications received from the French police.
Cross-examined by Launet. I produce the letters found at Newman Street.

Cross-examined by Linden. The books begin in various places—there were some expenses—about 70l. was received in about a fortnight, and out of the 200 letters 150 would contain a threepenny stamp—the entries do not occur twice in one book—there are not four clerks placed, but only one, at a French hospital—I had only a warrant against Barnard, but there is a warrant against all three of you for fraud in France.

CARLO GUIDA DE MOHR (Interpreted). I am a clerk and traveller of 11, Dean Street—I was employed at Barnard's—I cannot say in what capacity you (Launet) were there—you received moneys, whether as part
ner or how I cannot say—you read the letters—I have always given the same evidence before the Magistrates.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. When I went there first I saw L✗inden—he answered me as Barnard—he answered anybody who came the same as the others—Launet and Linden both wrote letters—I saw them—I was not paid regularly always—I did not deposit 10 francs—they did not ask me for it.

The prisoners in their defence handed in long written statements, Barnard and Launet in French, which were interpreted, and Linden in English, to the effect that Barnard established a genuine registry office for situations, that Launet was employed as a clerk, and Linden acted on his own account in the same way, but none of them wrote to foreigners to come to England, and those who did come had often other motives than to get situations; that they were innocent of fraudulent intentions, and the 10 francs were to cover necessary expenses.
(The whole of the evidence was interpreted to the prisoners. )

GUILTY . †—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour each.

p.hi: The Jury concurred in the commendation of the Grand Jury upon the way in which Inspector Moser had conducted the case.

div1.p: For cases tried on Monday, September 28th, see Surrey Cases.

884.
THOMAS KING (47)
PLEADED GUILTY to
stealing 30 yards of satin, the goods of
Thomas Adams and others.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour. And

885.
HENRY RUSSELL (23)
to unlawfully wounding
Emma Russell.—
Eight Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

886.
GEORGE BROWN (30),
Feloniously shooting at
Benedict Ziback with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

BENEDICT ZIBACK . I live at 143, Barking Road, Canning Town, and am a soda water manufacturer; the prisoner has been an assistant of mine nearly six years, and on 23rd July we agreed to part—about 2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 27th I went into my shop and saw the prisoner—he asked me to give him a written character—I told him I had not re
ceived one with him, but I would give him a verbal one—he walked deliberately out of the shop and said, "Governor, me and you have not done together"—about half-past 9 on the same evening I and my wife were sitting in the shop—it is wide open from the street—my face was towards the door—the prisoner came in and said "I have come for that character"—I said "George, I did not receive one with you, but I will give you a verbal one"—he then deliberately pulled a revolver out of his right-hand breast pocket—I heard the click and saw it pointed at me, and said "George, don't make a fool of yourself," and moved my head; as I said that the shot went by my ear—he said "Take that"—when he fired it I was sitting on one end of the seat, and he was standing at the other end—the seat is 4 feet long—I did not hear the breakage, but when I looked round I saw a looking-glass behind me broken, and the shot at the bottom of the corner, and it took a piece out of the wood—he turned round immediately and cocked the revolver again, I heard the click distinctly—my wife leaped at him and held him, and threw both her arms round him—directly I got up I said "Let him go, I will face him"—I was afraid he would fire at her—cries of "Police" and "Murder" were raised, and the police came—I did not see the bullet found.

THOMAS READ . I live at Canning Town and am a bootmaker—on 27th I was passing Ziback's shop and heard the report of a pistol and saw the prisoner come out of the shop with a revolver in his hand—I took it from him—this is it (produced)—he made no out-of-the-way resistance.

THOMAS PLANT (Policeman K 609). I was called to take the prisoner into custody—he said, "All right; take me out of this"—he was sur
rounded by a mob—he went quietly—I took him to the station and the prosecutor charged him with shooting him—I told him the charge—he said, "All right, I am glad I have not hurt him"—nothing had been said by or to him in my presence about Mr. Zibach not being hurt—this revolver was handed to me at the station—I examined it—it was loaded in four chambers out of five.

HENRY DAVIS (Police Sergeant K). I assisted in taking the prisoner in custody—on the way to the station he said, "I have worked for this man for five years and he has refused me a character; I did it in a passion"—shortly afterwards he asked, "Is he hurt?"—I replied, "I believe he is not" (I had not then seen Mr. Ziback), upon which he expressed himself glad—I afterwards went with Detective Dickers to the shop—I saw him find a bullet—I saw a mark on the wall about three or four inches in length and three-quarters in depth—the looking glass was penetrated through the front and a corner broken—the mark was exactly benind the looking glass and underneath it—the bullet was found six or seven feet from the mark on the wall at angles with the looking-glass.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I was guilty of firing the shot, but I was so excited I hardly knew what I was doing."
Prisoner's Defence. I am very sorry I fired the shot. I was so excited
I did not know what I was doing. I had been drinking that day and all the week before. I am very sorry for it. I never intended to hurt Mr. Ziback in any way.
THOMAS PLANT (Re-examined). The prisoner was quite sober.

GUILTY .—
Sixteen Months' Hard Labour.

887.
THOMAS DOBLE HOWARTH (30) was indicted
for a rape on
Ellen Louisa Pearce.

GUILTY .—
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

888.
WILLIAM STAGG (42),
Stealing a pair of boots, the goods of
Joseph Hull.

THOMAS FARROW . I live at 96, Leyton Road, Stratford, and am a farrier and assistant to Mr. Glover—on 21st July I saw the prisoner with Honeyballs in the Broadway, Stratford—the prisoner cut the string to which the boots were tied outside the door of No. 24, Mr. Hull's—he then handed the boots to Honeyballs, who dropped one of the boots but picked it up, and they walked on up to Kipping's, the greengrocer's, when the policeman caught hold of Honeyballs—the prisoner ran away—I am quite sure the prisoner was the man.

Cross-examined. You cut the string with a knife, and then the boots dropped—as I came home from dinner the constable said, "I have got the other man"—I had not seen you till that night—you cut the boots down.

WALTER HONEYBALLS . I live at Romford Street, Stratford—about 7 o'clock p.m. on the evening of the 21st July I was with the prisoner, whom I met against the fountains—he spoke to me and we went to this boot shop—he cut the string with a knife and gave me these boots—I dropped one of them by accident—the prisoner picked it up and gave it to me back—the policeman caught me—the prisoner ran away as hard as he could—I was convicted before the Magistrate for it—I told the Magistrate the prisoner had cut them down.
Cross-examined. I said you got me a month.
By the COURT. I have had a month, which is over.

JOSEPH HULL . I live at 24, Broadway, Stratford, and am in charge of this boot shop, which belongs to the Sterling Boot Company—I was in charge and had possession of the boots, these are they—I missed them on 21st July, they were worth 4s. 11d., they had been hanging outside my shop.
Cross-examined. I never saw you in my life before then.

GEORGE GREEN (Policeman K 321). I am stationed at West Ham—on 21st July about half-past 7 I moved him and Honeyballs from off the bank steps next door to the boot shop in the Broadway; I afterwards arrested Honeyballs with these boots on him—a week later, 29th July, I arrested the prisoner and charged him with being concerned with Honey-balls in stealing a pair of boots on the 21st from 24, Broadway, Stratford—he said "Honeyballs knows I would never have anything to do with him or any of his gang"—I took him to the station—he was placed with others and identified by Farrow, and when charged he elected to go before
a Jury: Honeyballs being summarily convicted by the Magistrate and sentenced to a month.
Cross-examined. Honeyballs said he would punch you on the nose for getting him a month.

GUILTY .—
One Month's Hard Labour.

889.
ISAAC WEBB (24),
Stealing two watches, the goods of
John Grindon.

JOHN GRINDON . I was a pianoforte, organ, and harmonium dealer and am now a watchmaker at 376, Barking Road, Canning Town—there is a glass case containing watches behind the counter, which you would have to go round to get at—at right angles to the counter is my work
ing-board, which a person must pass to get at the watches in the case—on 15th June I was in my little room, which leads through a door into the shop; both the shop door and the door between it and my room were open—I have a canary hanging at the back of the shop which generally makes a loud noise when strangers approach—I heard it between 15 and 25 minutes past 5 making a louder noise than usual—I immediately went into the shop, where I saw the prisoner standing at the far end of my working-board, between a piano and the end of the board—the public had no right to go there—he said "Have you any silver wires?"—I said "I have not"—he then left the shop immediately—I had seen two gold watches safe in the case at 8 or 9 a.m. on the 15th—directly the prisoner had gone I went over to the watch case, and I missed one of the watches there; I did not notice the other, because it had been behind some others—I went at once and gave information at the police-station, and when I came back I missed the second one—the value of the watches was about 16l., one of them was a gold repeater—I did not see what became of the prisoner after he left the shop—on 30th June I saw him at Chelmsford and was sure of his identity—the watches have not been recovered—I had not seen the prisoner before to my knowledge.
By the COURT. I knew him by his features—he seemed as I came into the shop as though he had just been in the act of turning round.

JOHN ROBERT LOWE . I live at 430, Barking Road, Canning Town, and am a music teacher—on 15th June I went into the prosecutor's shop about two or three minutes after 5, I stayed about 10 minutes, and left at about 12 or 13 minutes past 5—I noticed the case of watches, to the best of my belief I should say there were 30 watches in it; I particularly noticed a gold repeater there, I had seen it on several occasions before and had spoken to Mr. Grindon about it—I did not notice it as I went out—I did not notice anything about the other one.

JOHM GRINDON (Re-examined). From the time Mr. Lowe left my shop to the time the prisoner entered I heard no one else come in—the canary would give me warning when the door was opened—I came in directly after Mr. Lowe left—my wife is generally in the shop—there were two ladies in the house at the time and frequently in the shop—I gave directions that the shop should be watched on that day—no one else was in the shop when I came in, the door was shut when I came in—there is a bell which rings when any one comes in, it is up six feet high.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I went and asked your wife if her

name was Mrs. Webb—a woman was with her, I waited till she had gone—I gave your wife a shilling because I saw she had no food and was in distress—I sent a letter to her, I did not give her 5s. to go to you it Chelmsford and ask you if you knew anything about my two gold watches, and say that if you did not tell me what you had done with them I would go further into it; we asked for information to obtain a clue to the property, but we used no threat—this is the letter I sent your wife: "If you care to see your husband before the trial comes on I will pay your railway fare."

Re-examined. I gave her the 5s. partly out of charity and partly because I wanted to discover where my watches were—she did not come back—I had put the matter into the hands of the police before I gave her the 5s.—I paid her railway fare—I am satisfied as to the prisoner's identity.

RICHARD WILDEY (Police Inspector). From information received I went to Chelmsford on 30th July and took the prisoner into custody there—he knew me before—I said "I shall take you into custody for stealing some watches"—he stopped me and said "He wrote a letter to my wife telling her to come and ask me what had become of the pawn-tickets, and gave her 5s. to come and see me; and because she told him I knew nothing about them he said he would swear to me"—on the way to the station he said "Where were those watches from, Barking way?"—I said "Bark
ing Road"—he said "Yes, my wife told me so"—I had not mentioned Barking Road to him previously—descriptions of the watches have been circulated; they have not been recovered—the prisoner was living in Ocean Street, Stepney, three or four miles from the prosecutor.

LOUISA WALTON . I am a tailoress, of 66, Ocean Street, and am married—three weeks before 3rd August I was lodging in the same house with the prisoner's wife, occupying the front room upstairs—on the Tuesday the prosecutor called to see the prisoner's wife—I sent for her, and then went to my room upstairs, where I could hear what was said in the kitchen—the prosecutor said "Is your husband at home?"—he said "No"—he said "He is locked up"—she said "Yes, I know he is"—he said "I saw him in the Barking Road once, but I let him pass me, because I was not sure he was the man"—he wrote on a piece of paper which I saw afterwards the number of the watches, and his name and address—I know his hand from a letter he sent, which I saw a week afterwards—when he left the paper on the table he said "Be sure you don't show this to any one."

Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. I have been lodging with the prisoner's wife two years, and am doing so still—the prisoner was living with his wife in June; he went out at 7 in the morning and came back at 5—I don't know where he was working, I never asked him—when I first went he worked for his brother—on 15th June he went out and came home about the same time—we have lived at three addresses together during the two years—I said at the police-court that the prosecutor said he was not sure the prisoner was the man—the prisoner's wife gave me no papers to bring here—she had the paper the prosecutor left on the table, and the letter he wrote afterwards—I live in the same house still; they have left—I owe the prisoner's wife no money—we paid 6s. 3d. a week for the house; I paid 3s. for the top room.

WILLIAM KRITCHELL (Policeman K 97). The prosecutor came to me on 30th July, before the prisoner was arrested on this charge, and said "Have you got Isaac Webb in custody?"—I said "Yes"—he said "Did you search his premises about some watches?"—I said "I did, and found nothing relating to any property"—he said "How can I identify him?"—I said "It is not my place to tell you how you can identify him"—he said he believed he could identify him—I said "Oh" afterwards he said "I have been to his place, 66, Ocean Street, and I gave his wife 1s., since that I have given her 5s., for the purpose of going to Chelmsford to see him"—I said "I don't think you had any perfect right to go near the place after you had given information to the police."
Cross-examined. He didn't ask me by what means he could see him to identify him—the prisoner was in custody on another charge.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that he had never been near the place, and knew nothing of the watches.

div1.p: JOHN GRINDON (Re-examined). I saw the prisoner in the dock at Chelmsford Assizes with four or five others.
NOT GUILTY .

890.
WILLIAM WAKEFIELD (32),
Feloniously marrying
Amy Genisis, his wife being then alive.

SARAH RADFORD . I live at 1A, Craven Street, City Road, and am a costermonger, and the mother of Jane Radford—I was present when she married the prisoner at St. Mary's Church, Charterhouse, on 12th October, 1874—the ceremony was performed by a clergyman in the usual way—they signed their names in the vestry afterwards.

AMY GENISIS . I met the prisoner in Old Street, St. Luke's, and was married to him five weeks afterwards at St. Thomas's Church, Bethnal Green, on 13th April, 1885—he has since ill-used me very much, knocked me about, and ill-treated me.
Cross-examined. I did not instruct a solicitor to prosecute.

ROBERT DAY . I got the certificates, and now produce them. (These were certificates of a marriage at St. Mary's, Charterhouse, on October, 12th, 1874, between William Wakefield, bachelor, and Jane Radford; and the other of a marriage at St. Thomas's, Bethnal Green, 13th April, 1885, between William Wakefield and Amy Genisis.)
Cross-examined. I did not instruct Mr. Hadley to prosecute—the first wife is still alive—she was here yesterday—I have not seen her to-day.

SARAH RADFORD (Re-examined). My daughter is alive—about a year and a half ago the prisoner came to my place and asked where my daughter was—I said I did not know—he said if I found her they would be happy and comfortable together, and next day he came round and they went home and into my bed.

GUILTY .—
Four Months' Hard Labour.

891.
JAMES DOOLEY (20)
PLEADED GUILTY ** to
unlawfully wound
ing
Bridget Swanson.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

892.
HERBERT GEORGE POWELL (20),
Feloniously shooting at
Henry Powell with intent to disable and do him grievous bodily harm.

HENRY POWELL . I am the prisoner's brother, and am a steam-hammer driver—he is 19 and I am 21—on 11th August I lived at 34, Patterson Road, Plumstead—my brother and I occupied the same sleeping apart
ment prior to Friday, August 7th, we had been on bed terms, and on the night of that day we had a quarrel together, and he said if I did not let him be he would shoot me—I knew at that time that he had a revolver to his possession—he had it in his hand when he said he would shoot me—he did not do anything with it that night—on Saturday afternoon, about half-past 2, when I went home I found him in the bedroom—as I was going towards the door, which was open, I believe I heard a report of two pistol shots, and rushed into the room and took hold of the pri
soner I could not say who he fired them at, but hearing them I rushed into the room and found him there—I caught hold of him and started beating him, and took revolver away from him, and another shot went off in the struggle—I then ran out into the yard and jumped over the fence into the next yard and went down to the Magistrate at the police-court, and obtained a warrant, and handed the revolver to the inspector—I did not examine it before I gave it to him, but I saw him look at it—my brother was then taken into custody upon that warrant—there were six chambers to the revolver I believe—I had not interfered with it from the time I took it away from my brother to the time I gave it up to the police constable.

Cross-examined. I said on another occasion "Before I got into the house I heard a report"—I was then about 100 yards from the house, down the street—I heard the second shot while I was in the yard, going towards the bedroom—I believe the back door was open—I cannot swear to it—when I entered at the back door I had to go along a passage before I got into the room where my brother was—I had not to go upstairs; it was on the ground floor—the window of the bedroom looked into the back yard—the door opened into the said of the passage—I cannot recollect whether I opened it or whether it was open—there is only one window to this bedroom; I believe that was closed—I was still in the yard when I heard the second shot—I have said on another occasion that the third shot went off in the struggle.

ELIZABETH POWELL . I am the mother of these two young men, and keep a greengrocer's shop at Patterson Road—on Saturday afternoon some one called and said my two sons were fighting in the yard—I was upstairs—I at once went down into the yard and got between them and tried to part them—I then saw that the Prisoner's mouth was bleeding very much, and he pointed and said his tooth was knocked out, and I looked and saw that it was—the last witness jumped over the fence and went away after two or three of us came to the rescue—I saw the small revolver some weeks before, but heard no report—I did not see it on this afternoon—Henry was the worse for drink, but I never knew the
prisoner to be so—I knew he had this revolver—I thought he kept it in his box.

JOHN GILLARD . I live at 16, William Street, Woolwich, and work in the tailor's shop at the Royal Arsenal—I know the prisoner and his brother—on 6th June I went with the prisoner to a shop in Plumstead Road, where he bought a revolver and 25 cartridges for 8s. 6d.—this (produced) is the revolver—he laid he bought it to frighten his brother because he was always knocking him about—on Saturday afternoon, the 8th, the prisoner came to my house and said his brother had come into the room and started knocking him about, and said, "You b—, I will get drunk for you this afternoon"—he said he jumped out of window and caught hold of a broom, and his brother jumped at him and knocked out his tooth, and he paid, "I took the revolver out of my pocket and fired, and Henry took it away and jumped over the wall"—he said, "I want to buy another revolver"—I went with him to Andrews's, a gunsmith's, and he gave me the money to buy a revolver for 13s. 6d.—this is the revolver; it has six chambers—I also bought 50 cartridges for 2s.—I gave him the revolver and cartridges—he loaded the six chambers—he said he bought it in case his brother started on him again—he said his brother had not knocked him about so much since he bought the first revolver.

EDWIN COUSINS (Policemen R 315). I was at the police-court when Henry Powell came there—this revolver was handed to me there by the gaoler; I examined it—it is a six-chambered revolver; neither of the chambers was loaded, but there was an empty cartridge in one, as if it had been let off; the other chambers had the appearance of having been let off—a warrant was obtained, and on the same Saturday night I saw the prisoner in Poole Street—his brother was with me—I said to him, "I shall take you on a warrant for shooting at your brother Henry this afternoon"—he replied, "I will hang for the b—"—I took him to the station and charged him—on searching him I found this six-chambered revolver fully loaded with ball—after the charge was read over he said, "It is not true"—I went to the house and looked in the yard and bed
room and passage to try and find marks of a pistol-shot, but could not; I looked all round the bedroom where a shot was likely to hit.
NOT GUILTY .

893.
HERBERT GEORGE POWELL was again indicted
for a common assault on the said
Henry Powell, to which he
PLEADED GUILTY .—
To enter into his own recognisance to come up for judgment when called upon, and to keep the peace towards his brother. Henry Powell also entered into his own recognisance, and to find one surety, to keep the peace towards his brother for one year.

894.
ALFRED JONES (17)
PLEADED GUILTY* to
burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Lee, and stealing therein a coat and other articles, his property.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

895.
SOPHIA BEECROFT (50),
Robbery with violence on
Aaron Cohen, and stealing a purse, 20 pawn-tickets, and 16s., his property.

AARON COHEN . I am a fitter, of 26, Tiverton Street, Oakley Square—about midnight on 18th August I lost my train from Maize Hill, and went to look for lodgings—I met the prisoner, who said, "Where are you going to?"—I told her I wanted lodgings—she said, "If you will treat me I will direct you"—I gave her a penny and she directed me—about 10 or 15 minutes afterwards she came up again and said, "Where are you going to now?"—I said, "I am going in the direction you directed me"—all of a sudden I felt a hand in my trousers pocket—I laid hold of her wrist and struggled with her—she halloaed out, "Phil, Phil," and a man struck me on the back of my head—I struggled with him and held him down; he held me down by the throat while the woman took my purse; I saw her take it—they both got away—I lay for some time, as I was hurt—I only saw her about a second the first time and about a minute the second time—I had a good opportunity of seeing her face—I was not tipsy—I described her to the police, and afterwards identified her from three others in a private house; she was partly dressed and partly in bed—at the station she said, "I never see the fellow before, I do not know him"—she took 16s. from me; and about 20 pawn-tickets, value 15l., but I stopped those.
JOSEPH WILL (Policeman R 42). From a description of the woman's features and her name "Phil" which were given to me I arrested the prisoner—the prosecutor was sober.

JOSEPH JOYCE (Detective Officer R). I have known the prisoner about two years—I have made inquiries, and can find no woman named Phil going about with another named Sophie—the prisoner's house is at Greenwich.

p.hi: The prisoner in her defence stated that she knew nothing about it and never saw the prosecutor before, and that he could not identify her or say whether she wore a hat or a bonnet.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

896.
JOHN WATKINS (29)
PLEADED GUILTY to
indecently assault
ing
Fanny Elizabeth Bull.—
Three Months' Hard Labour. And

897.
WILLIAM TERRY (25)
to indictments for forging and uttering en
dorsements to orders for the payment of 18l. 5s., 77l. 12s. 6d., 64l. 8s. 3d., and 143l. 2s.;
also to embezzling the said sums of the
Metropolitan Gas Company, his masters.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

898.
MARY EMBEY ,
Unlawfully obtaining by false pretences half a leg of mutton from
Edward Gurney.

EDWARD GURNEY . I am a butcher, of 86, Powis Street, Woolwich—on 19th July, about 3 p.m., the prisoner, who I had not seen before, came in and said she wanted a bit of meat—she fixed on half a leg of mutton—I wrapped it up and gave it her, and said "Who is it for?"—she said "For Mrs. Farley in Wellington Street"—knowing more than one Mrs. Farley in that street, I asked which one it was for—she said "For the photographer's wife"—she had on a dark hat and a short mantle or jacket—she was in the shop about five minutes; she was differently dressed then—I next saw her at the police-court—I picked her out from two other women about two days after; one was con
siderably
older—I knew Mrs. Farley, the photographer's wife, and believed she came from her.

Cross-examined. I instructed no solicitor to prosecute—I was shown into a room at the police-court after waiting a quarter of an hour—there were three or four average aged women there—the prisoner was not so old; she was the only person wearing a hat—I told the police the woman who came into my shop wore a hat; the others had bonnets on—I had never seen any of them before—I gave her the meat before she said it was for Mrs. Farley—I thought she was a respectable woman—a detective came for me to go to the station next day—I did not give a description to the police—Mrs. Farley's husband did—I did not interfere till the police called on me, and said they had got a woman in custody who answered the description, and wanted me to identify her—there are two Mrs. Farleys in Wellington Street—I first asked her if she was the photographer's wife after she had the mutton—I have not got the mutton back.
Re-examined. I would not have let her take the mutton out of the shop unless she had mentioned the person's name—she had a different hat at the station.

FREDERICK ALEXANDER (Detective Officer). I took the prisoner on 1st August, two days after—I read the warrant to her, and told her I should have to take her in custody on the charge in the warrant—she said she did not have the meat, neither had she been out of the house on the afternoon of the 29th.

Cross-examined. We received no description of the woman from the prosecutor—he picked out the prisoner from among two other women who had bonnets on, and were working men's wives; one was much older and the other about the same age, not over 40—I made no note of the conversation with the prisoner—I have given from my memory exactly what she said—I said at the police-court that she said at the station "I met Mrs. Farley; she got some steak and gave it to me"—I said before the Magistrate on the second occasion that she said she had not been out on that day—I signed my deposition knowing it appeared there. (This did not appear in the deposition.) Wellington Street is in the immediate neighbourhood of Mr. Gurney's shop.

ELIZABETH FARLEY . I am the wife of Thomas Farley, a photographer of 74, Wellington Street, Woolwich—I know the prisoner—I did not send her on 24th July to purchase mutton for me—I had given her that morning 2 lb. of steak for her husband's dinner out of charity—I thought she wanted it; she is a tradesman's wife.
Cross-examined. She has lived in Woolwich some time; there is no difficulty in finding her.
