MR GEOGHEGAN submitted that the false pretences being subsequent to the meat having been obtained there was no case to go to the Jury. The COMMON SERJEANT considered it was a question for them. The Jury, without hearing MR. GEOGHEGAN, returned a verdict of
NOT GUILTY .

899.
ELIZABETH SAUNDERS (29),
Stealing a purse and 17s., the goods of
Frederick Bartlett.
FREDERICK BARTLETT . I am a navvy, staying at North Woolwich—on 26th July I met the prisoner and went home with her—I gave her

3s., which she put on the mantel-piece, and said she was going to leave it there for the night—I undressed and put my purse, in which were 17s., in my right-hand trousers pocket, putting them under the pillow where I was going to lie—soon after the prisoner left the room, leaving me in bed—I lit a light, got out, and found my trousers were taken from my pillow and down at the foot of the bed—I found the purse and money gone—I dressed and went into the street, where she was drinking beer with four men under a wall opposite—I told her I should give her in charge—she swore at me and said she did not care if I did—I walked up the street, saw a constable, and gave her in charge.

HENRY RUTHERFORD (Policeman R 227). On the 26th July Bartlett gave the prisoner into my charge about 11.30 p.m. for stealing a purse containing 17s., some halfpence, and pawn-tickets—I told her the charge—she said, "I know nothing at all about it; he gave me 3s., to go home with me, and I know nothing more about it. I came out"—she was searched at the station by the female searcher, and 8s. 6d. was found on her, all in shillings and sixpences, no papers or anything else—Bartlett was quite sober, the prisoner was not; but some time had elapsed between the time it happened and her being taken.
FREDERICK BARTLETT (Re-examined). I first saw her about 10.30 or not so late—my money was all silver, half-crowns, shillings, and sixpences.

GUILTY . She then
PLEADED GUILTY * to a previous conviction in October, 1884.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

900.
WILLIAM TAYLOR (19)
PLEADED GUILTY to
obtaining by false pretences from
Edward Willis a quantity of cigars with intent to defraud.—
To enter into recognisances to come up for judgment if called on.

901.
HENRY CURTIS was indicted
for that he, being Relieving Officer for the parish of Wandsworth, did unlawfully and wilfully refuse to give
Sarah Wright an order upon the medical officer to attend her child,
Edward Wright, in consequence of which he became ill and died. Second Count, for neglect of duty, whereby the life of the child was endangered.

Before plea taken MR. FULTON applied to quash the first Count, as it disclosed a case of felony, viz., manslaughter, and submitted that there was no statutable jurisdiction which enabled a pleader to state as a misdemeanor that which on the face of it was felony. MR. JUSTICE HAWKINS declined to quash the Count. Thereupon the defendant (by advice) declining to plead to the first Count, a plea of
NOT GUILTY was entered for him; and to the second Count he PLEADED NOT GUILTY.
ATHELSTAN BRAXTON HICKS . I am barrister-at-law, and am Coroner for the Kennington District of the County of Surrey—on Wednesday, 5th August, I held an inquest at the Spread Eagle, Wandsworth, which

was continued by adjournment on the 10th, on the body of Edward Wright, a child aged seventeen months—these (produced) are the desposi
tions which I took—the prisoner was examined as a witness, and I took down his evidence.

EDWARD HARRISON TAYLOR . I am Clerk to the Guardians of the Wandsworth and Clapham Union—the prisoner was one of the Relieving Officers for the district of Wandsworth—he had been so since November, 1883—I have the minute book here containing his appointment—he was furnished with the "Relieving Officers' Manual," containing the orders of the Poor Law Board of 24th July, 1847, and the order of the 14th December, 1852.

Cross-examined. If the officer gives relief to a person who the Guardians think ought not to be relieved, the account would be submitted to the District Auditor, and if he thinks fit the Local Government Board would surcharge him—the Relieving Officer has a certain discretion in the matter of relief—the Guardians are no parties to this prosecution.

SARAH WRIGHT . I am the wife of John Wright, a carman, of 9, Iron Mill Road, Wandsworth—we had a little boy named Edward, aged 17 months—he had been under the doctor—on 1st August he was taken suddenly ill with bad diarrhoea and sickness—be got better, and went on pretty well till the Saturday following; about 9 o'clock that morning I went to the prisoner and said "Please, Sir, will you give me an order for my child, he is very bad indeed with diarrhoea, and might be dead before I get back"—he said "Go and find your husband"—I said "I do not know where to find him, he is away at work"—he was at work that week, but he had been out of work—his wages were 22s. a week if he went on Sunday morning—the prisoner did not give me any order, he kept saying "Go and find your husband"—he never had given any order to my husband, he always gave it to me—I have nine children now, I had ten with this one—some of them were out in the street—all of them live at home—the eldest is not 14, the next is a little over 12, the next not 11, and the next not 9—my husband leaves home for work at half-past 4 o'clock in the morning, and returns between 7 and 8 o'clock—the child died at 3 o'clock on the Sunday morning—I had no money to pay a doctor—my husband would bring his wages home on Saturday night.

Cross-examined. My eldest child earns 4s. a week, which he brings home to assist in the maintenance of the family—the deceased got a little better on the Saturday morning after I returned from seeing the prisoner, and he was better when my husband returned, between 7 and 8 o'clock—he brought home 1l. 1s. on the Saturday night, which he had earned, and the eldest boy brought home his 4s.—the child was asleep when my hus
band returned—I put him to bed with the others, and he went to sleep about 8 o'clock; the diarrhoea began again just after 12 o'clock—he had always been a delicate child from six weeks old—I did not send out my husband or boy for a doctor, we did not think he was so bad; we did not think there was any danger—there was no doctor very near—we occupy the whole house, and pay 6s. a week, we don't let any of it—my husband had been out of work for a month—I knew I should have 25s. that night, but I owed a lot out of it—it was no use going to Dr. Nicholson without an order; I have always had orders before—I had no money to pay for a doctor.

By the JURY. None of my children hawk in the street; one has sold watercresses, but not now, they are all over—he would not earn 1s. a week he only goes out on Sundays—the dispensary is a quarter of an hour's walk from our place—Dr. Nicholson would charge 2s. for a bottle of medicine—he had always attended the child—my husband was dis
charge from his place not through drink, they were slack; he has gone back to the same place.

JOHN WRIGHT . Up to 25th July I had been out of work—my late employer started me again on Monday, 27th—I was to have a guines a week, and 1s. extra if I worked on Sunday—I had been at work every day that week—on Saturday morning, 1st August, I left home for work at Wimbledon at 4 o'clock—I knew the child was ill, and told my wife to go to the relieving officer for a doctor—I got home between 7 and 8 o'clock—the child was much better—it became worse at midnight, and it died at 3 o'clock on 8unday morning—I brought home my wages, a guines; we were in debt—I had to pay my rent and keep my wife and family for the next week.

Cross-examined. Between 12 and 2 o'clock the child was very ill with diarrhoea; it stopped again—I had not the 25s. then, nor yet 1s., it was all laid out except 1s. or 2s.—I gave it all to my wife and she laid it out—I did not go for a doctor because I did not think there was any danger—the child was teething—I was discharged in consequence of slackness of work, nothing else; I was taken on again and hare been there ever since.

RICHARD LAMBERT LAMPREY . I am a registered medical practitioner it Wandsworth—in August I was acting as substitute for Dr. Nicholson, the parish medical officer—if an order had been given by the relieving officer it would have been my duty to attend to this child—I had attended it in September, 1884, for a short time—on 2nd August I saw its dead body—I made a post-mortem examination—there was no mark of violence, and no particular disease—the organs were healthy, except that they were anaemic—the cause of death was exhaustion from diarrhoea—a child of that age suffering from diarrhoea ought to be medically attended at once—if this child had been seen during Saturday it might have had a fair chance of living

Cross-examined. If medical aid had been obtained at midnight there is a probability that it might hare lived—I cannot say with confidence that it would—diarrhoea is amenable to treatment as a rule—I am not sure whether in an urgent case I should be entitled under the Poor Law orders to give relief—I have told them to go and get an order—I can't say that I have given relief first.

p.hi:
submitted that there was no case to go to the Jury; the only offence, if any, which the prisoner had committed was an error of judgment; that the evidence left it in doubt what the actual duty of the prisoner was, or whether in such a case as this he was not allowed a certain amount of dis
cretion.
referred to the case of Clark v. Jocelyn, 27th New Series, p. 762, and contended that there was a sufficient evidence of neglect by the prisoner for the Jury to act upon.
left the case to the Jury.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

hi.rs: There was another Indictment against the prisoner for the manslaughter of the said child, upon which no evidence was offered.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

902.
WILLIAM BILLINGS (19),
For an indecent assault upon
Caro
line McCarthy.
NOT GUILTY .

903.
HENRY GODDEN (30)
PLEADED GUILTY to
unlawfully at
tempting to abuse
Edith Emily Brett, aged 8 years and 6 months.—
Two Years' Hard Labour.

904.
WILLIAM BARBER (26),
Breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Hudson, and stealing a watch, a pair of ear-rings, and other articles, his property.

GEORGE MITSON . I am a shipping agent, of 7, Adelphi Villas, East Dulwich—on 17th June, about 8.30 a.m., I left my house locked up safely—I returned about 6 o'clock and found the front door forced open, some drawers and boxes broken open, and I missed a gold watch, a meerschaum pipe, some ear-rings, and other things, worth 10l. or 15l.—I have not seen them since.

MARIA GILLARD . I live at 6, Adelphi Villas—on 17th June, about 1 o'clock, I saw two men passing—they stared at the house next door very much; they were a very short distance from me—about 5 o'clock I saw the same two men come out of Mr. Mitson's house and walk down the pavement—the prisoner is one of the me; I saw his full face—he had a bandage on his hand as if it was hurt—he had a bowler hat and a loose coat—I saw the prisoner a week after with five other men; I knew him directly—I said "He is the third man from the bottom" without hesitating, and that was the prisoner.

Cross-examined. I was looking out at the window, which is level with the ground—I had to look across the garden; there were no plants to obstruct the view—the window was shut—I saw their full faces as well as their side faces—my evidence was read to me before the Magistrate, and I believe I said he was the man—I won't swear I did not say "I can't swear he is the man"—I have not talked about it to the police-man.

AMY GILLARD . I lire at 6, Adelphi Villas, East Dulwich—on 17th June I was at the window and saw the prisoner knocking at a house—half an hour after, he passed with a man and stared at me—he had one hand bound up—he had a felt hat and, I believe, a blue coat loose—I saw him with four other men three weeks after, and identified him at once.
Cross-examined. No one was with me—Maria Gillard is my mother—she went to the station when I did; she went in first—I don't think she spoke to me when I came out.

FREDERICK GREY . On 27th June I saw the prisoner at the corner of George Street and Blackfriars Road dressed as he is now with another man, and saw him go to a pawnbroker's—on 19th June, about 11.30 p.m., I saw him at the White Hart, Gravel Lane, wearing a blue jacket, and his right hand bandaged—I went to his house on 27th June, and found two jemmies, a screw-driver, a hammer, a file, and spoons—I had followed him there—I took the jemmies to the prosecutor's house and compared them
with the marks on the drawers and the cash-box, and they corresponded—there were 14 places where the jemmy fitted, ad into the door as well.
Cross-examined. A jemmy has not particular teeth by which you can reooguise the marks—I was five yards from the prisoner face to face—he had a hand kerchief round his finger then.

ESTHER BEARD . I live at 13, Surrey Road—on 6th May the prisoner came to lodge at my house, and his wife remained till July 1st, but he was taken before that—I gave him notice to leave, as he used to come home at 2, 3, and 4 a.m.—when the police came they found two house-breaking jemmies.
Cross-examined. He never wore a blue serge coat or jacket to my knowledge, nor have I seen his hand tied up with a bandage.
Re-examined. He went in and out for days together without my seeing him at all—I sometimes saw them pass the kitchen area.

ALFRED WARD (Police Sergeant L). On June 27th, before 1 a.m., I saw the prisoner at the corner of George Street, Black friars Road, with another man; they looked up at a pawnshop door and at the window, but on seeing me they moved away rapidly, and we lost sight of them—I saw them again at 1.15 at the corner of Surrey Road—Grey and I went to them; Grey got hold of one, and I got hold of Barber, and said "I am a police officer, and I take you in custody for loitering, supposing you to be about to commit a felony"—he said "You have made a mistake; I am going home"—I asked his address; he refused it—I said "We happen to know your address from having watched you on Wednesday night"—I went with Boswell and Grey to 13, Surrey Road, and found a box, which I unlocked with one of four keys which I found on the prisoner, and which was indicated as being his by a prostitute with whom he lived.

Cross-examined. I have been over 17 years in the police—I have not often seen a jemmy like this; it is of superior manufacture—Jenkins, who was with him, has been dealt with in another place, and sent to prison for not reporting himself.

FRANCIS BOSWELL (Detective Sergeant L). I was with Ward when he took the prisoner—I went with him and Grey to the prisoner's lodgings, and found three jemmies and two door wedges, a knife, a hammer, and some plated spoons—I opened the box with a key which Ward handed to me, and saw another box with a number of pawn-tickets in it—I returned to the station, and said to the prisoner "What is your name and address?"—he refused to give it—I pointed to the tools—he said "You have helped me, go and help yourself."

GUILTY . He then
PLEADED GUILTY ** to a conviction of felony at this Court in the name of James Reid in June, 1878.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

905.
ALFRED DE NEGRI ,
Indecently assaulting
Mary Ann Avings, aged 12 years, and
Annie Elizabeth Harwood, aged 11 years.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character, and the Jury being unable to agree were discharged without giving a verdict. On a subsequent day the prisoner was tried before another Jury, who found him.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

906.
GEORGE SIMPSON (30),
Feloniously assaulting
Edward Fun
nell, with intent to rob him.

EDWARD FUNNELL . I am a barman at 6, Wimpole Street, New Cross—on 30th July, about 1 a.m., I was in High Street, Borough—the prisoner came up and said, "I want some money"—I said, "I have no money to give you"—he said, "I must have some money"—I slipped off my watch and chain and put them in my pocket—he whistled, and three more men came up and rifled my pockets—I called "Police," and the prisoner tripped me up; I fell on the side of my head and got a severe cut through the fall, from which I am suffering now—a policeman came and took him off me.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not ask you for assistance or strike you.

CHARLES BORMAN . I am a hairdresser, of 198, Walworth Road—on 30th July, about 1 a.m., I was in High Street, Borough, and met the prosecutor, the prisoner, and three more men—I heard the prisoner say, "Stick to him, he has got some money"—I saw the three men try to rifle his pockets, and the prisoner kept hold of his arm and had his fingers in his waistcoat pocket; he shoved him and tried to get him round the corner—the other three ran away, and the prisoner took hold of Funnell and pitched him on his head—I saw him taken in custody.

WILLIAM WALTERS (Policeman M 393). I was on duty with Bannister, and saw the prosecutor and prisoner speaking together—the prosecutor shouted out, "Let me go"—I thought they were larking, but I saw the prisoner throw him down and hold him down—I rushed up and pulled him up, and money fell—the prosecutor was injured, and the doctor at the station said that it was a very serious case—2d. was found on the pavement, and I found 10d. on the prisoner.
HENRY BANNISTER (Policeman M 135). I was with Walters—I have heard his evidence, and corroborate it.

p.hi:
The prisoner in his defence stated that he saw three men knocking the pro
secutor about, who called on him to assist him, which he did, and afterwards went to a coffee-stall, and then saw them struggling together again, and went to pick the prosecutor up and was taken in custody.

div1.p:
GUILTY .—
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

907.
ALFRED SMITH (16),
Stealing 6l. 10s. of
Caroline Sarah Rice in her dwelling-house.

CAROLINE SARAH RICE . I live at 11, Lordship Terrace, East Dulwich, and am the post mistress there—on 9th September, about 10.30 a.m., I was in the parlour, and saw through the window the prisoner behind the counter—I went into the shop, and he had got his hand in the till—I said, "What are you doing there?"—he came towards me, and I took hold of him—he struck me a blow on my face which sent me back against a case, and he got away—there was about 7l. in the till, and 6l. 10s. in gold and silver was taken—the prisoner was brought back, and I am sure he is the man—I said at first that I did not think he was the man, but afterwards I changed my opinion.

ADA CHARLOTTE STONE . I live in the same house as Mrs. Rice—I heard her screams—I looked out of the window and saw a young man run out—I ran after him—the prisoner is the man—I have no doubt about him—some men took up the chase and he was taken.
HARRY RICHARDSON . I am a carpenter, of 5, Padua Road, Penge—

on September 9th, about 10.30, I was opposite Mrs. Rice's post-office and saw the prisoner run out—I chased him about a mile and caught him without losing sight of him—when he came out another man was standing outside the shop who ran towards Lordship Lane—I took the prisoner back.
GEORGE BYWATER (Detective P). I found the prisoner detained at the station—Mrs. Rice charged him with stealing£5—he made to answer—I found 6 1/2 d. in bronze on him.

GUILTY .—
Nine Month's Hard Labour.

908.
JOHN ELKINGTON ** (29)
PLEADED GUILTY to
unlawfully obtaining food and money at an hotel by false pretences;
also to stealing two umbrellas and other articles, the goods of
John Cummings, having been convicted of felony at Clerkenwell in November, 1879—
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour. And

909.
WILLIAM FENNY (14)
to unlawfully wounding
Alexander Worthy.—
Four Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

910.
HARRY JAMES ,
Feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of 9l. 8s., with intent to defraud.

GEORGE RICHARD TOOKE . I am managing clerk to Messrs. Smith, Stenning, and Co., of Aldermanbury—the prisoner has been in their employ about eight years—on 12th May 9l. 8s. was due to Mr. Heath for fees—the prisoner drew this cheque by my directions for that amount (produced)—the body of it is in the prisoner's writing, and this is Mr. Stenning's signature—the prisoner's duty was to pay it to Mr. Heath—I did not see it again until, I think, 6th July, when my cashier called my attention to the endorsement, apparently in Mr. Heath's writing—I know his writing; it is not his, though very much like it—I showed it to Mr. Heath—after that I asked the prisoner what made him do these things—he said he was very sorry—there were several cheques drawn on the 12th May.

Cross-examined. The prisoner came to us from Kirby, Gedge, and Millett, the Solicitors to the School Board, with 6 years' character—he was their assistant Chancery clerk—we entrusted him with lump sums of money to disburse—he would have to render us an account, not at stated times, but not more than a week would elapse before he did so—if he used any of this petty cash for his private purposes, and then accounted for it at the end of the week, no particular objection would be made, unless damage resulted to a client.

Re-examined. We did not recognise his taking cheques drawn for par
ticular purposes and cashing them, or putting other people's names on cheques—there were other acts of dishonesty on his part—certain papers were not to be found which were found afterwards.

By MR. AVORY. That was one of the matters I complained to him about when I spoke to him—there was a question of his not stamping some deeds, and the whole matter was investigated by Mr. Stenning, not in my presence—there was some salary due to him, and it was set off against that.
By MR. MEAD. Mr. Stenning dismissed the prisoner, I understand.

JOHN HAYDON . I am an omnibus conductor, of 23, Sulina Road, Streat
ham Road—the prisoner lodged with me—on 30th May 1 was outside the

White Lion, and he asked me if I knew where he could get a cheque changed—I asked him if it was all right—he said, "Oh, yes"—I said, "Perhaps Mr. Hornsby, the manager of the White Lion, might manage it," and we both went in together—Mr. Hornsby aaid he made it a prac
tice never to change cheques for strangers, but if he would leave it he would pass it through his bank, and if it was met he could have the money, and it was left—on the following Wednesday I was going to the Derby with a load of passnngers; the prisoner met me on Brixton Hill, and we went to the White Lion—Mrs. Hornsby gave me the money, and I handed it to the prisoner.
Cross-examined. There was no arrangement for the prisoner to go to the Derby, or for the day the money was to be paid.

WILLIAM HENRY HORNSBY . I keep the White Lion at Streatham—on 30th May the prisoner and Haydon came—Haydon asked me to change a cheque—I refused on principle, but it was left with me, and I gave the money to Haydon next day.

WILLIAM BAILEY HEATH . I am a barrister-at-law—on 12th May 9l. 8s. was due to me from Messrs. Smith, Stenning, and Croft—I never received this cheque in payment—this signature at the back is not mine, but it is a good imitation.

Cross-examined. I know the prisoner—he was in the habit of attending to professional matters for Messrs. Smith, Stenning, and Croft—I con
sidered him a respectable man up to this transaction.

ARTHUR SEARLE (Detective W). On 22ud July I apprehended the pri
soner, and charged him—he asked me where my information was derived from—I said, "From Mr. Hornsby"—he said, "Have you seen Mr. Heath, and what does he say"—I cautioned him that what he said would be men
tioned against him at his trial, and he said no more—he was then taken to Streatham Station and charged.
Cross-examined. I arrested him where he was lodging with his wife and family—neither Mr. Heath, Mr. Hornsby, or Mr. Stenning instructed me to take him in custody.

WILLIAM HENRY HORNSBY (Re-examined). After receiving a letter from Mr. Stenning, holding me responsible to repay the money, I gave infor
mation to the police.
By MR. AVORY. I am independently responsible for these proceedings, because I put the letter into the hands of the police, but Messrs. Stenning do not make me so now.

GEORGE RICHARD TOOKE (Re-examined by MR. AVORY ). Mr. Stenning did not give the prisoner in charge—sometimes in the fortnight's settle
ment 3l. or 4l. would be found due to the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

911.
GEORGE D1XON (23) and
ARTHUR GREE (23),
Robbery with violence on
Laurence Kiernan, and stealing a trinket and other articles, his property.

LAURENCE KIERNAN , M.D. I live at 9, Pear Tree Street, Waterloo Road—on 10th June about 9.30 I was in Cornwall Road—the prisoner Gree knocked against me, snatched at my chain, and I found my locket was gone—he went down King Street with a person similar to Dixon—I followed, crying "Stop thief," but lost sight of them—I gave informa
tion
, and about a week afterwards I went to the station and identified Gree at once, and I thought Dixon was the other.

FREDERICK ROBINSON . I am a painter of 17, Wootton Street—I have known Dixon three months and Gree 18 months—on 10th June I was outside my door and saw them followed by the doctor, who was calling "Stop thief"—I am certain they are the two—I heard Dixon say "I have done the doctor of something worth 20l. "—I afterwards went to the station and identified them.
Cross-examined by Dixon. I did not say that I saw Gree give you the locket when he was running.
Cross-examined by Gree. I did not swear that you gave Dixon a locket while you were running—Dixon said that about having done the doctor outside a public-house, I did not then say that you said it.

ALFRED WARD (Police Sergeant). I received information on the morn
ing of 11th June and made inquiries, and on 7th August, about 1 a.m., I saw Dixon at a coffee-stall in Blackfriars Road—I told him he answered the description of a mad I was looking for for a robbery on 10th June—he said "I think you have made a mistake"—the prosecutor saw him at the station next day and identified him, not positively, but to the best of his opinion, as the man who ran off with a darker man on the night of the robbery—he said on the way to the station "If you will get the Magistrate to admit me to bail I will take you to the shop where the locket was sold for 5s.; I did not steal it myself, I only ran after Gree to see what he had got"—on the morning of July 27th I saw Gree at the police station—I said "I have been looking for you, Gree, some time," and told him what he was wanted for—he said "I don't think that is quite right," but when he was before the Magistrate he pleaded guilty to the robbery—he was placed with others,.and the prosecutor identified him.
Cross-examined by Dixon. You told me where you worked, and inquiries were made by another officer.
FRANCIS BOSWELL (Detctive Officer). I was with Ward when he arrested Dixon.
Cross-examined by Dixon. I went to your wife and made inquiries and then went to where you worked as a wire worker, as you said—I found that you did the work at home.
Dixon's Defence. It was this man who did the robbery. I worked at Swan and Edgar's and at the Incorporated Stores, and it would not pay me to disgrace myself.
Gree's Dejence. I did it through starvation. Robinson brought the man to me who planned the robbery.

FREDERICK ROBINSON (Re-examined by Gree). I did not come round Broad Walk and plan the robbery; I was at work; I work at Simpson's in the Strand, and am never done till 8.30—I was just coming out at 9.30 on this night—I did not rob a child of a loaf and put it under my coat, and afterwards throw it at a man—it is all false.

By the prisoner Dixon. I have always been an honest man—I did not kick a man in the testicles and ruin him for life—just before you were arrested you both assaulted me outside the White Horse, and threatened me if I gave evidence against you.
FRANCIS BOSWELL (Re-examined). I can confirm Robinson—I saw him in a most pitiable state.

GUILTY of robbery without violence.
GREE then PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction at Clerkenwell in June, 1882, in the name of James Butler. DIXON—
Four Months' Hard labour.
GREE **—
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.

912.
WILLIAM SMITH (19)
PLEADED GUILTY to
unlawfully utter
ing counterfeit coin.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

913.
RICHARD BANKS ** to
feloniously uttering counterfeit coin after a conviction at this Court in December, 1881.—
Two Years' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

914.
HENRY SMITH (37) and
CHARLES HIGGINS (20)
to burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Ashton, and stealing a piece of meat. SMITH also PLEADED GUILTY ** to a conviction of felony at this Court in September, 1883, in the name of George Wells.—
Five Years' Penal Servitude.
HIGGINS **—
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

915.
HENRY KING (18)
to stealing a bicycle, the property of
Charles Stevenson, and another bicycle, the property of
Edward Carey; also to a conviction of felony** in October, 1884, in the name of Henry Esser.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

916.
CHARLES WATKINS CRESSY (37)
to six in
dictments for forging and uttering accountable receipts for various sums of money, with intent to defraud. The prisoner received a good character.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

917.
GEORGE H1CKMAN (20),
Robbery with violence on
Philip Humphries, and stealing a watch, his property.

PHILIP HUMPHRIES . I am a marble mason, of 142, Kennington Road—on Saturday night, 22nd August, a little after 12, I was in the Lamb✗th Road going home, when the prisoner met me, struck me in my face with his fist, and knocked me down—I fell on my back on the pavement stupefied for a moment—when I got up my watch was gone, and the prisoner had run away—he was brought back by a constable in less than two minutes—I charged him; he was taken to the station—I am sure my watch was safe in my pocket a few minutes before—my coat was open.

Cross-examined. I had had something to drink in the Ship, Kenning
ton Road, and the City Arms in West Square; no others—I did not have a good deal—I was in bad health, and what I had affected me—I don't remember everything that occurred—I have no recollection of going to a coffee-house in Joyner's Street with a woman that evening—I would not swear I did not—I did not know there was a coffee-house in the street till the following Monday—I had looked at my watch a quarter of an hour before—I walked straight; I did not roll about—I left the public-house at 12—there were clocks in the public-house—I was with nobody in the public-house—here is the mark where the prisoner struck me, and the back of my head was sore afterwards—I know he is the man by the parties that saw it, and I saw him under a lamp—he had a billycock hat on—I did not strike him with my stick—I was not sober.

GEORGE CAPES (Policeman L 33). At 12.15 on 22nd August I was on duty in Joyner'a Street, and saw the prisoner knock the prosecutor down under a lamp-post—he walked towards me—I stopped him and said "What is the matter?"—he made no reply—I said "You had

better come back and see"—we did so—the prosecutor was getting up; his watch-chain was hanging down—he charged the prisoner—I saw no one else about there but Field—I did not see the prosecutor running after any one with a stick.
Cross-examined. I searched the prisoner at the station—I found no watch on him, only a few halfpence.

JOHN FIELD . I am a bricklayer, of 103, Kennington Road—I was going down the Lambeth Road on this evening and saw the prisoner knock the prosecutor down and then hurry round the corner of Joyner's Street, and then the policeman brought him back—I saw no one else there.
cross-examined. I did not see the prisoner take anything out of the prosecutor's pocket—I was fifteen yards away.
NOT GUILTY .

918.
WILLIAM MARTIN (50),
Feloniously uttering counterfeit coin.

EMILY WATERHOUSE . I am barmaid at the Crown and Anchor, New Kent Road—on July 23rd, between 7 and 8 p.m. Ann Greeson (See next case) came in for 2 1/2 d. worth of gin—I served her—she tendered a half-crown—I tested it and gave it to Mrs. Cross, the landlord's wife, who broke it—Greeson then gave me 2 1/2 d. and left the house—the landlord fallowed her.
Cross-examined. I did not see you in the house.

JAMES BURTON CROSS . I keep the Crown and Anchor—on the night of the 23rd July Emily Waterhouse called my attention to Greeson leaving—I followed her and saw her join the prisoner, who appeared to be waiting for her—they stood talking together for a considerable time, then crossed the road, and Greeson entered a-provision shop—when she came out they parted, and the prisoner went into a house—I went into the shop and communicated with Mrs. Garrett—she showed me a half-crown—I went after Greeson—she was walking away towards the private house into which the prisoner had gone—I charged her with uttering to me and Mrs. Garrett charged her with uttering to her—later in the evening I went to the police-station and there saw the prisoner and Greeson together—when confronted he said, "That is my wife"—she said, "That is not my husband"—I went to Page's Walk, Bermond
sey, that evening with Lainohbury, the house into which I had seen the prisoner go.

Cross-examined. I was a quarter of a mile from my house to where I saw you join Greeson on the way to Mrs. Garrett's house—Greeson only went into Mrs. Garrett's before going home—she went partly in and partly out of a private house.

LUCY GARRETT . I am a widow and keep a provision shop at 209, Grange Road—about 8.30 p.m. on 23rd July I served Greeson with three penny eggs—she tendered a half-crown—I gave her change—the instant she had left Mr. Cross came in and made a communication to me, in consequence of which I examined my till and found this bad half-crown, which was the only one there—Cross left me and fetched a constable and Greeson, and I charged her with uttering—she was very boisterous with the policeman and threw the good change down on the counter—she was taken away in custody.
JOHN DUNN (Policeman M 68). On this night I was called to Mrs.

Garrett's, where I found Greeson detained—I took her in custody—she endeavoured to bite my hand, and was very bad indeed—I had to get assistance to take her to the station—on the way I got her hand open alter some time and in it found five counterfeit half-crowns, wrapped in tissue paper, which was rubbed off in the struggle getting her to the station—there were about 300 people round us, and it was raining and the paper got wet—she was searched by the female searcher, and in her hand were these two keys, and a purse containing 6d. in silver and 2 1/4 d. iu bronze—in consequence of something she said I went with Lainchbuy to 28, Page's Walk, Bermondsey, quite near, about 11 o'clock, where I found the prisoner in the water closet with his trousers on buttoned up, and in his stockings—Lainchbury said, "You are wanted, for your wife has been passing bad money down here in the road"—the prisoner said, "I know nothing about it"—Lainchbury took him to the station and I went for Mr. Cross, who picked him out from among a Jot of men—the prisoner said, "She is my wife," but she said, "I don't know the man; he is not my husband."

GEORGE LAINCHBURY (Police Sergeant S). At 10.30 p.m. on 23rd July I went with Dunn and Gaertner to 28, Page's Walk, of which house Mrs. Darwin is the landlady—after being kept at the door some time we went in and searched a back room which she showed us—we had a con
versation with her, and then examined the w. c. in the back yard, where we found the prisoner fully dressed, except his coat, waistcoat, and boots—we pulled him into the back parlour, the room he occupied—I said, "A woman is in custody in Bermondsey Street for uttering counterfeit coin; she says her husband lives here; you will have to accompany me there; it has been said that a man has been seen in her company, and if you are identified as that man you will be charged"—he said, "I have never been out of the house; the landlady can prove that"—he was very lofty—he said, "My wife has been out"—I said, "If she went out and picked up with a strange man it is rather unfortunate"—I sent Dunn for Mr. Cross, and then took the prisoner to the station, where I placed him among others—he was picked out by Mr. Cross without any hesitation—Greenon was fetched out of her cell, and the prisoner said, "That is my wife"—I said, "Is that the man you refer to"—she said, "No, I don't know anything about him; I don't know him at all; that is not my husband"—I took this bag, which I found locked on a table in the back room where the prisoner lived, to the station—the small key found on Greeson opened it (I could put my hand in through the ends before)—I took it back and locked it in the room till the following Sunday—subsequently I examined it carefully, and found in it a new pocket-knife, two pairs of socks, and a piece of paper—I went early in the morning after the prisoner's apprehension to 28, Page's Walk with Gaertner—there is a small back yard with a fence eight feet high round it, and adjoining is a piece of waste ground, in which, about seven feet from the fence, and directly adjoining the w. c., I found this packet, containing 11 counterfeit half-crowns, each wrapped separately in tissue paper—the paper found in the bag is exactly similar to that in which the half-crowns were found—the packet was lying on the surface of the ground as if it had been quite recently thrown there.
Cross-examined. You were sitting on the seat of the w. c. awake, I should say—your dress was not disarranged—the door was not locked—

if you were asleep I pulled you by the arm, and I dare say that woke you up—there is no lid to the closet—I first turned the bag out in your pre
sence—I was searching for money—I put back everything in the bag, and it was locked up in the room—on Sunday I searched it again in Mrs. Darwin's presence—I had not noticed the paper the first time—when the inspector asked me what there was there I said, "Nothing we want"—the inspector did not say, "Then we must discharge them, there is nothing against them"—I found the paper in the bag on Sunday—the bag was locked up in the room during the interval, and the key was in my pos
session.

MANY ANN DARWIN . I live at 28, Page's Walk; the prisoner occupied a room there on 20th July with Greeson as Mr. and Mrs. Martin—between 8 and 9 o'clock on 23rd July the prisoner asked me if I would lend him the street door key as his wife had gone out with the key on the ring—shortly afterwards the constable came and took him—the bag was locked up in the room till Sunday by the constable, who had my key I then saw the constable search the bag, and saw a piece of brown paper taken out—I had not seen the bag open before.

Cross-examined. I had seen you about 7 or 8 o'clock that evening in the back parlour—it was about 7.30 when you asked for the key—you went out with Greeson before that—about 7.30 I said your missus had gone out, and you went out alter her—I gave you the key—about an hour after you came in, but 1 did not know you were in the house after 7.30—I had been out all day, and came home about 4.15—I found the place in a disgusting state of filth, and the woman drunk on the bed—I saw nothing of you between 5 and 7 o'clock—there is a factory clock outside the window which we look at.

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . Mrs. Garrett's half-crown is bad—these five found in Greeson's hand are bad—none of them are from the same mould—these 11 half-crowns found in a packet in the waste ground are all bad; two are from the same mould as Mrs. Garrett's—counterfeits are wrapped up separately in tissue paper generally, after being rubbed over with lampblack to keep them bright—I see no marks on this paper.

p.hi: The prisoner in a written defence denied having been out with Greeson on this night, and stated that he got drunk and went to sleep on the w. c.

div1.p:
GUILTY . He then
PLEADED GUILTY ** to a conviction at this Court of uttering counterfeit coin in the name of William Jackson in February, 1882.

919.
WILLIAM MARTIN was again indicted with
AMY GBEESON (27)
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin and having others in their possession.

WILLIAM SHORT . I live at 195, Essex Road, Islington, and am a tool dealer—on 1st July, about half-past 3, Greeson came in for a key ring, which would be 1d.—I think my assistant Holden served her—she tendered me this half-crown—I told her it was bad—she said "Give it to me back, and I will take it where I took it from"—I asked her where she took it—she said "I took it from over the way," pointing to a public-house—I said I would go over with her and see her right—on the way she said it was not there she took it, it was a house down the street—I followed her and then she turned back, and asked me not to give her in charge, but to
give her the half-crown—I said I would not leave her till I gave her in charge—1gave the half-crown to Blake in my shop, and charged her.
CHARLES BLAKE (Policem N 618). William Short gave Greeson into my custody on 1st July—she was charged at Clerken well, remanded till the 8th, and dicharged.
The evidence of EMILY WATERHOUSE, LUCY GARRETT, and GEORGE LAINCHBURY in the last case was read over to them by the shorthand-writer, to which they assented.

p.hi: assented to his evidence in the last case.

div1.p: Cross examined by Martin. When you went in the house you stopped—Greeson first went in the doorway and came our again, and went to Mrs. Gurrett's—I presume you were at home when she passed the half-crown there.

JOHN DUNN (Policeman M 68). On the night of 23rd July I was called to Mrs. Garrett's, and Greeson was given into my charge; Cross alto charged her—she said her husband had given it her—afterwards at the station she said a man gave it and the other coins to her for stopping with her the night previous—then she said I should find him at 28, Page's Walk, in consequence of which I went there—she was violent going to the station, and tried to throw the packet away all the time.
MARY ANN DARWIN . The two prisoners lodged with me at 28, Page's Walk from 20th July, occupying the back parlour as man and wife in the name of Martin.

p.hi: Greeson in her defence stated that the man, who was a stranger to her, gave her the bad money.

div1.p:
MARTIN—
GUILTY .—
Eight years' Penal Servitude. GREESON—
GUILTY ** on the Second and Third Counts.
—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

p.hi: commended the constables for their conduct. The
assented in this and also commended Mr. Cross.

div1.p:
920.
ALFRED ORME (27),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

FRANK BARTON . I am barman at the Pear Tree, Lower Marsh, Lambeth—on 11th July the prisoner with another man and a woman came in, and the prisoner asked for a pot of four penny ale and tendered this half-crown—I bent it in the tester and handed it to Mr. Hart, the landlord—I went for a constable, and the prisoner left the house while I was gone—I was not present when he was taken in custody.

CORNELIUS MCAULIFFE (Policeman L 108). On 11th July I saw the prisoner at 10.20 p.m. with two other men, one of whom was his brother, and a woman, enter the Pear Tree—about half an hour later Barton called me in—the prisoner was not there, but his brother was.

ANNIE CHILD . I am barmaid at the Waterman's Arms, Belvidere Road, Lambeth—between 1 and half-past on 1st August the prisoner came in for twopenny worth of rum and tendered half a crown, which I put in the till and gave him two shillings and fourpence change—about 9 o'clock that evening he came in again for twopenny worth of rum and tendered this florin—I examined it and bent it and showed it to Miss Soott and then to Mr. Scott—he spoke to to the prisoner, and then the constable came in and asked the prisoner where he got it—he said on a racecourse, and that he did not know it was bad.
Cross-examined. You were the last man 1 served before I went to dinner, you gave me a half-crown; I cannot swear it was this one.

ROBERT SCOTT . I am landlord of this house—Annie Child handed me this florin—I saw it was bad; I asked the prisoner where he got it—he said "On a racecourse"—I gave him in custody with the florin—he told the constable not to be tricky, or he would be tricky with him—he gave evasive answers, and I charged him because he would not give a satis
factory account—I afterwards examined my money-bag in consequence of something told me, and among 24l. 7s. taken that day I found this half-crown, the only one there—I can't swear it is the one the prisoner tendered.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You did not say you had been moving some goods for a gentleman.

MICHAEL DORAN (Policeman L 48). I went into this house and re
ceived from Mr. Scott this florin—I asked the prisoner where he got it—he said "I picked it up on a racecourse"—I took him to the station—he said "If you are going to be tricky I shall be tricky with you"—he kicked very violently—I said "Where do you live?"—when I got to the station he said "I refuse my address"—I found on him 6d. in silver and 4d. in coppers, good money.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You Kicked me on my knee.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These coins are both bad.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that he had no knowledge that the florin was bad, and that he knew nothing of the other coins, and that another man had been charged with uttering the one at the Pear Tree.

div1.p: CORNELIUS MCAULIFFE (Re-examined). The prisoner's brother was taken to the station, but discharged by the Inspector.

921.
CHARLES SMITH (23),
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

ROSANNAH TILBURY . I am the wife of Henry Tilbury, a greengrocer, of 24, Westmoreland Road, Walworth—on 8th July I was serving in the shop—a man tendered me a shilling, which I showed to my husband, and then gave it back to the man, who left.

HENRY TILBURY . I am a greengrocer, of 24, Westmoreland Road—between 7 and 8 p.m. on 8th July I saw my wife serve the prisoner and receive a shilling from him—I spoke to her; she showed me a bad hilling; she gave it back to him—on 15th July, about 8.30 a.m., my wife made a communication to me, and I went over to Sarah Vincent, at 23, Westmoreland Road, just opposite—the prisoner was detained there—I went to the station and charged him with uttering to my wife on the 8th—I picked him out at the police-court from eight or ten men—I have not the slightest doubt about him—I did not see him at Mrs. Vincent's—I was riding in my van a little distance off.

SARAH VINCENT . I keep a provision shop at 23, Westmoreland Road—at 8.15 on 15th July I served the prisoner with fourpennyworth of goods—he tendered this half-crown—I gave him two shillings and two-pence—I had two customers in the shop—I kept the half-crown in my hand, and as soon as I had served them I looked at it—I found it was bad—the prisoner had left the shop, but I know him, and knew he lodged at Levy's lodging-house not far off—I got there as he was entering the

door—I said "Do you know what you gave me?"—he said "Yes; a half-crown"—I said "Do you know what it was?"—he said "No"——I said "Do you know who gave it you?"—he said that a gentleman gave it him between 4 and 5 a.m. in the Haymarket—a crowd collected—I asked him to give me good money and I would give him the bad back, and would not prosecute him, but would leave others to prosecute him if he tendered it again—he agreed to that, and gave me 2s. 2d.—I went to my shop—the police came for me, and I went to the station and recognised him.

JOSEPH BESLEY . I am a mendicity officer—I was present at the con
versation between the prisoner and Mrs. Vincent—I followed him when he went away—he said to those with him, when he got inside the passage going into the house, "All right, I have got the half-dollar"—I touched him on the shoulder and said, "Governor, I want to speak to you out-side, I am a police officer, I shall take you to Carter Street on the charge of having bad money in your possession, and also having just passed bad money"—he said, "Let me go back and put these things down"—I took him to the station—on the way he said, "I got the half-crown given me in Pall Mall between 6 and 7 or 7 and 8 last evening."

ARTHUR HULL (Policeman P 607). I was on duty at the station when the prisoner was brought in—in answer to the charge he said that the half-crown was given him that morning between 3 and 4 o'clock by a gentleman in Pall Mall—I found on him 1d. and a key—I was present when Mr. Tilbury picked him out from seven others without hesitation.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . This half-crown is bad.
HENRY TILBURY (Re-examined). I took the shilling to be bad by the colour and weight; I bent it between my fingers.

In the case of
JANE BODGER , indicted before MR. JUSTICE HAWKINS
for wilful and corrupt perjury, during the progress of the case the Jury intimated that they did not wish the case to proceed further.
NOT GUILTY .
